18622278.review:
我给出的评分：7/10

特立独行，但又鹤立鸡群的一款独立游戏。推荐在30%及以上折扣时购买。

优点

1：很有趣的日系主题。

Lovely Planet，可爱的星球，正如标题所指，从进入游戏界面的关卡，到游戏内的场景，敌人，障碍物，全都是日系画风的萌物，连敌人扑街时说的最后一句话都是日语。游戏过程中不会像其他FPS一样鲜血横飞，十分适合玩完恐怖游戏之后缓解一下情绪。

不过这款游戏的主要的开发者并不来自日本——他来自印度。

2：玩法独特，考验走位，预判能力和背板能力。

游戏中的敌人的攻击方式就是以不高的射速朝你吐紫色方块，而你需要用手中长得像弓一样的东西射出紫色方块来打到他们；这时考验的就是走位和预判了。为什么需要预判呢？因为你的子弹飞行速度并不快，比敌人的子弹速度快不了多少，而这款游戏并没有准星，此时就需要预判了。

当他们吐得子弹向你飞过来时，你可以选择打中他吐得子弹，这样可以使子弹反弹从而打倒敌人；或者靠走位躲开子弹，并通过预判进行跑动射击。前者的好处是不需要很高的预判技巧，缺点是你不得不停下来射击，而这会耽误时间；后者正好相反，需要一定的预判，但同时能节省时间，毕竟这每个关卡都会计算时间的。

除此以外，游戏中还会有在地上蠕动的红色史莱姆和会朝你飞过来的大苹果，前者打不打无所谓，如果挡道路了就一枪解决，而后者则必须在落地前打掉，因此预判在这时就显得尤为重要。

这款游戏之所以考验背板，是因为所有的敌人和史莱姆，苹果的初始位置都是一成不变的，如果你想要在规定时间内顺利通关的话就必须要背板。

3：很欢乐的BGM

正如这款游戏的名字一样，它的BGM也很Lovely。欢快的主旋律很贴近游戏整体明快的色调和风格，即便脱离游戏本体，这款游戏的BGM也十分讨喜，值得为此购买OST。

缺点

1：没有准星的设计是手残玩家的噩梦。

2：游戏本身没有一个剧情，仅仅是控制主角四处打怪而已，如果能加入为什么会有怪物出现在这个Lovely Planet上的剧情，那么这款游戏还能获得更多正面评价。

3：游戏中只有一种武器可选，寥寥可数的几种敌人和障碍物。如果能加入一些有其他攻击方式的武器，或者其他有挑战性的敌人，相信这款有戏会更加有趣。

4：游戏没有联机模式，不得不说是一个遗憾。几个基友互相无脑突突突还是比较欢乐的。

总结

一款很可爱但又兼具难度的另类FPS游戏，适合战争和血腥玩的太多，想要“换换口味”的FPS玩家。当然，如果你真的手残的话，这款游戏也绝对能把你虐出翔。

18546613.review:
[h1]Niedlich und unglaublich hart[/h1]

Tja, Lovely Planet ist ein lustiges Spiel, in dem es eig. darum geht, schnell durch die Level zu kommen. Für mich bestand aber erstmal die Aufgabe überhaupt mal durch die Level zu kommen. 
Lasst euch nicht von der netten und kindlichen Grafik einlullen, das Spiel hats faustdick hinter den Ohren.
Es gibt 5 Welten und in jeder Welt haben sich die Entwickler was noch fieseres und hinterhältigeres einfallen lassen. So muss man sich beeilen um herabfallende Äpfel abzuschießen und wird zeitgleich von nem Gegner beschossen, dessen Schüsse einen verfolgen und man die Schüsse dabei auch "abschießen" muss. Ich kann nur sagen, dass Lovely Planet zwar die liebe und nette Atmossphäre rüberbringt, aber einen gleichzeit  mit einem 20 Tonnen Panzer überfährt :D

Fazit:
Ein lustiges Spiel mit einer knappen Spielzeit (vielleicht 4-5 Stunden maximal) um die Level zu schaffen. Die Bestzeiten sind entweder gehackt oder von einem typischen Super-Japaner aufgestellt worden, sodass man die einfach net schlagen kann. Aber trotzdem kann ich Lovely Planet echt empfehlen, wenn Einem sowas liegt.

17581735.review: Lovely Planet is a competitive tactical 5v5 FPS game with a complex skill curve. The teams are divided into two teams; counter-terrorists and terrorists. Your role as a player is to shoot your opponents while avoiding getting shot. Getting shot will instantly result in a death since everyone has AWPs. You have to watch out for grenades as well, as they are also instant-kill and have a massive radius. To avoid these, you have to shoot them like what kennyS did in SS7. The top players are either extremely good and have spent a lot of time in this game, or have just abused bugs/exploits/hacks/etc. Matchmaking is very fast with each game taking <10 seconds to begin. Everyone who I have met was friendly, especially Penguin-san. I'm probably going to play a lot more of this.

17434223.review:
[b]If Super Meat Boy meets Katamari Damacy meets FPS[/b]

A first person shooter where the objective is to be quick and precise, to get to the end of each short, challenging level as fast as possible. 
If Super Meat Boy was a First Person Shooter, this game is exactly what it would be. 

The controls feel crisp and responsive. 10/10 in that department. 

Some of the music and graphics sound and look like they were taken directly out of Katamari Damacy on PS2, which isn't really a bad thing.

Lovely Planet is a really, really fun game that will give even hardcore gamers several hours of enjoyment. I highly recommend this game.

17329440.review:
Глядя на чересчур положительные отзывы от людей, чьё время в игре составляет два часа и менее, решил вставить свои пять копеек по поводу этого шедевра. 

Пройдя Hotline Miami, решил взять что-то новое, купил одну бесполезную игру по предзаказу, а стим мне ещё решил посоветовать Lovely Planet, "похожее на то, во что вы играли". Ну, почему бы и нет. за 29 рублей то. 

Глядя на скриншоты игры, можно решить, что это какая-то простенькая бродилка, скорее всего рассчитанная на детскую категорию. Обычно такие игры целиком проходятся за пару часов и забываются тут же. Однако, данная игра [i]чуть-чуть[/i] не такая, какой пытается казаться. 

Итак, что же тут есть? Игра состоит из ~100 уровней на пяти мирах. Каждый уровень можно пройти за 5-20 секунд, больше вряд ли найдется. Цель нашего путешествия - уничтожить всех красных врагов и прибежать в финальному розовому столбику для перехода на следующий уровень. Вроде всё просто и понятно. Однако, вся эта простота заканчивается довольно быстро. Во втором мире у нас, помимо красных террористов, стреляющих фиолетовыми кубами, появляются во врагах падающие яблоки (томаты?), которые надо сбить до того, как они разобьются об землю. Уже в данный момент игра намекает, что стоять на месте она не позволяет, а кнопку W отпускать - для слабаков. Далее появляются враги, снаряды которых имеют самонаведение, а лететь они будут за нами до победного. Стреляют они, кстати, почти также, как и в вышеупомянутой HM - лишь завидев и именно в нас. К четвертому миру нам добавляют "туман войны", из которого по нам стреляют невидимые недруги, а на пятом появляются ещё и телепорты. 
И, складывая все эти причуды в один уровень, получается адский коктейль из боли, кучи рестартов и горения. Прицела тут у нас нет, а отбивать фиолетовые кубы иногда приходится в довольно массивном количестве, да к тому же очень быстро. Постепенно время прохождения уровня длинной в десять секунд доходит до двадцати, а то и более минут и ты начинаешь потихоньку ненавидеть эту игру. 

Чтобы добить, хочу поведать также о достижениях в этой игре. Да, их мало, и большую часть получить довольно легко. Кроме тех, где написано Unlock all stars. Что в этой игре значит то, открыть все звездочки? За каждый уровень, как и в какой-нибудь игре на телефоне, нам могут поставить от одной до трех звезд. Первая звезда дается за прохождение уровня, да и только. Вторая за то, что мы уложились в отведенное игрой время на этот уровень. Третья - наша точность должна быть 100%. Попробуйте пройти так, дальше второго мира вы вряд ли уйдете. У меня и на него терпения не хватило.

Основные положительные качества этой игры - музыка, по одному треку на каждый мир. К сожалению, только по одному, потому что постепенно вам придется слушать их довольно много. Но она не напрягает, по крайней мере первые минут тридцать. Вторая положительная сторона - графика. Игра выглядит довольно мило, особенно в сочетании с музыкой. Яркие и по-своему красивые локации под не менее милое музыкальное сопровождение. 

Подводя итог, не советую брать эту игру тем, кто грешит метанием клавиатуры и мыши в экран - шанс точного броска с этой игрой возрастает. Однако, если вы любитель спидранить игры, и высиживать хардкорные уровни вам по душе, а Press R to restart вам душу радует, то почему бы и нет. Тем более, в игре есть таблица рекордов, так что можете попытать счастье и поставить лучшее время на каком-нибудь уровне. А я жалкий казуал, который сгорел от этой игры, потому не рекомендую.

Отредактировано во имя значка.
И ещё раз.

17328852.review:
So nearing the amount of in game time that equates to 10 actual rotations of the Earth (228.6 hours at the time of this review), I feel as though I have a proper understanding of this game, and my input will be valued.

Short version: This game is superb. You'd have to be an absolute fool to neglect this purchase.

Long version: My roommate suggested me this game after learning that I was looking for games to speedrun. I purchased it, fired it up, and not a moment later, fell in love with it. That kind of love you feel that just warms your whole body. My initial reaction was, "Wow, this soundtrack is incredible! And these graphics! It's so simple, yet so capturing and quirky!"

I started on 1-1. The first level in the first world. As the music changed from the Menu music to City, I got swept away in a feeling of bliss I hadn't felt in years. The controls were simple, the enemies were clear, and the objective straightforeward. Use the keyboard to move and jump, use the mouse to look and shoot. Reduce the enemy count to 0, and walk into the purple pillar. So simple! Why aren't more games like this? 

As you reach the goal, a new window shows up, displaying information such as how quickly you completed that level, how quickly other people completed the level (a leaderboard), as well as how quickly the fastest person completed that level. Just like that, you already have a new way to enjoy the game, as if the gameplay itself weren't enough. Now you can not only compete against your own times, but other people too? Game on.

As you try to get top 15 times on the leaderboards, you start to try new things. Push the routes you used to take, or plan entirely new ones, hoping that they're faster. As you inevitably burn through all the levels in City, you move on to world 2, named Village. With each new world, new levels, obstacles, and enemies stand between you and those sweet sweet top 15 times. Can you hack it?

This game is designed in a way that the player doesn't feel coddled, but at the same time, it's not impossible to win. It's designed to be challenging, but not unwinable. New enemies are revealed in open, contained areas that let you see how they function, before throwing them just around a corner in the last levels of that world. 

227 in game hours ago, I had the biggest, stupidest grin on my face. The joy of this game hasn't left me, even 227 hours later. If you're looking for a fun casual game, then you've found one. If you're looking for an speedrunning game that puts your skill to the test, then you've found one. Buy. This. Game. It's worth every penny.

Note to potential speedrunners: This game contains little RNG. The only RNG it DOES contain, bears no effect on how the game is run, or how it affects you or enemies. The only RNG occurs when an enemy dies, or your bullet registers as a hit, your gun will be showered in stars, providing a visual cue so the player can continue without having to watch the shots connect. I can find no pattern to where the stars appear. This is the RNG. That's it. This is an extremely skill and execution based game.

Este es Lovely Planet desde mi punto de vista:

Lovely Planet es un juego de plataformas donde encarnamos a un ser que armado con un arma que lanza proyectiles.Nuestra mision es simple, conseguir pasar los niveles en el menor tiempo posible eliminando a todos los enemigos y evitando a toda costa que te maten a ti.

Los primero niveles son juego de niños y te impresionaran más que nada por el estilo artístico que por su difucultad.

Este juego está basado en mundos a lo ''Mario Bros''  pero  al final del nivel no habrá un Warrio que tenga a la princesa.

A cada mundo (como es evidente) la dificultad aumenta, pero a veces llega a un punto impresionante en el que te pasas los niveles a golpe de ratón, literalmente, aparecen tantos enemigos y manzanas que el juego se hace muy rápido, cuando digo muy rápido, es muy rápido, tanto que a veces o en mi caso, se hará algo frustrante, no es un juego ultra dificil, pero no es un juego''Lovely'' ya me entendeis.

Lovely Planet, Ah yes. Lovely Certainly describes this game.
This is literally my favorite game I've [b]ever[/b] played. It’s amazing from its quick paced FPS shooting to its not obvious in your face, but certainly there story line. This game is trippy cute and simply beautiful. Yes as most people will argue that it’s just the "basics of unity" but it’s the simplicity that makes it what it is. 17092585.review:
Lovely Planet is a FPS platformer in a surreal and cute world. However do not let the cuteness fool you, this game is brutally hard.

The graphics remind me of the Nintendo 64 games with crude 3D shapes mixed with occasional simple 2D textures to give character. I know this is a bit far-fetched, but I find it cute in Lovely Planet.
The gameplay is swift and responsive, the only weird part being sliding off some ledges that look like it would be possible to land on them. Framerate is perfect and the game runs well. However the FOV cannot be changed.

The idea is to get across a short level while jumping on platforms and shooting baddies. Simple enough, so there are leaderboards to compete, and stars given according to accuracy and speed. At first I kept trying to go faster and faster without understanding why my impressive runs didn't get rewarded by the game, until I learned that the third star was only given for 100% accuracy. I like a good challenge, so I worked on finishing all levels 100% with three stars.

At the start the levels were pretty straight-forward and it was fun. But then... then the apple fell too far from the tree. Literally, because falling apples is the one game mechanic that ruined the game for me. Any single apple hitting the ground triggers a game over. The early ones are thrown at the player, which is fine. However after a bit the apples are shot in the sky from a different place in the level, and just fall right where they are, whether the player is around or not.

Let me explain better how this is infuriating. You are in a part of the level, merrily shooting and platforming your way. And then, suddenly, you cross an invisible line and hear the dreaded sound of an apple been released. And now, the only thing that you can do is rush forward in the level to reach the part where the apple is located, and start shooting from afar (because the bullets take time to travel), without a target nor a crosshair, where you predict that the apple is going to fall . And then you realize that three apples were triggered, and you need to pre-shoot three different locations with pinpoint pre-accuracy and timing. So, basically, you have no choice but to quickly shoot in several directions and hope for the best, and do it again and again until you are a robot that has complete muscle memory of the right way to deal with this nonsense. And let's not talk about the moment where you have to jump on a jump-pad, and while in the air, shoot where an apple is going to land BEHIND you, then quickly turn back forward and shoot where an apple is falling in FRONT of you. I managed to do it. I did all of this. I had three stars in these levels, so 100% accuracy. But instead of being happy at my achievement, I was thinking "why? why so much time wasted being a robot and not having any fun?". Then I started the 4th world, and noticed that the levels were engulfed in fog. Superman 64 level of fog and fun. With the nerve-wrecking treat that I also had to pre-shoot apples that I couldn't even see, and it was made even more obvious that completing the levels would be a tedious chore of memorizing every single move and shot. 

No, thanks, I like a good challenge, but this is just a waste of time, and the cute graphics are hidden in fog anyway, so why bother. Goodbye Lovely Planet, I only recommend you at a very cheap price to fool around in the early levels, otherwise I do not think that you are a good game worth investing my time and sanity to complete.

16954191.review:
You have to shoot all the targets and run to the finish of the level, which takes about 15 seconds when you succeed. This game starts off easy but gets really difficult. Your projectiles are slow so you have to lead moving targets, and you fail the level if you let some targets hit the ground or get hit by an enemy projectile. The gameplay is very trial-and-error. You have to figure out a sequence of shots and moves and execute them close to perfectly, or you'll fail. To give you an idea: often you have to jump into a teleporter after which you are greeted by three projectiles flying at you from different directions, so you have to shoot them to not get hit, but at the same time jump on a disappearing platform and reach around the corner just in time to hit two tomatoes before they hit the ground. Very difficult. For enthousiasts, there are achievements for being fast and for 100% accuracy in each level.
If you like difficult/trial-and-error games with instant restart (such as Super Meat Boy), get this game. But don't expect a lot of variety. There are about a hundred levels and they all look similar.

16874553.review:
[i][Skip to the verdict if you want a short summary][/i]
[h1]What is lovely planet?[/h1]
Lovely planet is a twitch first person shooter rage game platformer thing. In the game you traverse through different colourful levels, trying to kill alll enemies, not miss any shots and beat your time. It may sound easy but believe me when I say [b]it's not...[/b] there will be many obstacles alog the way.

[h1]The love and the hate[/h1]
If you rage easily in games dont get this, okay? Most of the time you will be repeating the same stage time after time again because you made stupid mistakes. The other portion of the time you will be smashing your keyboard and screaming words that you didnt even know you could say. But: Im not saying thats a bad thing because its not. It adds to playtime and it make winning a level feel very rewarding.

The two most amazing aspects of this game for me are the artstyle and soundtrack. It really makes me chuckle when I realise Iv been screaming at a bunch of colourful polygons and a happy japenese tune. They both remind me alot of Japan and I think thats what they were going for considering the random japenese writing everywhere. The artstyle consists of minimilistic colourful blobs that make it easy to tell enemies and ground apart with their colours that stand out. The music in itself makes the game. The music is a nice upbeat happy track which makes you forget about all your troubles and just stand and listen. It is so happy I wonder how it could be played over the top of such an evil game! In fact I am listening to it while reading this review and it makes me not want to list a bad point about the game!

The gameplay in this game is the usual. Considering that it is mainly concentrated on platforming and twitch shooting which I hate it still felt smooth and I felt as if my shots were hitting when they should. The gun felt nice although you couldnt change what gun you had which I thought would of been cool although it probably would of messed up the leaderboards for speedrunners. So I think this game could use a bit more variety to make it a bit more intresting and unique.

Something this game is missing is a story which although twitch shooters dont normally have a story I think that super meat boy pulled of a pretty nice story so this could probably do it to! I felt as if that made the world I ran through feel empty and without meaning. Also I think a story would of made me want to progress a bit further into the game whereas right now Iv given up because Iv been stuck for an hour. Also It might add to the replayability.

[h1]The verdict[/h1]
Lovely planet is a rage inducing twitch shooter with platforming aspects. Its soundtrack and world makes up for the lack of story. Beware you may break something.

[b]Love[/b]
+Soundtrack
+Graphics
+Gameplay
+Long playtime

[b]Hate[/b]
-No story
-Rage
-Variety

[b]6.5/10[/b]

Here is an example of what you may be up to in a random level in this game (whole process takes around 7 seconds):

- jump to a small self destructive island

- during the jump shoot falling object (it began falling during your previous jump) behind the hills
- find a safe place to land near the finish mark

even if you manage to reach the finish mark you fail if one of following conditions is met:

- you left any of 2 enemies alive
- falling object hit the ground

16734269.review:
I don't normally write reviews, but after finishing this wonderful game, I can't help but try to convince others to give it a try. To start, Lovely Planet is a game about shooting angry red guys. In order to get all 3 stars for a level, you must kill every enemy, beat the level fast enough, and not miss a single shot. With the low shot speed of your bullets, this last one can be a pain, but all of the game's enemies are stationary (except for apples, which can hardly be considered enemies) and you'll get used to the gun. 

The game has great visuals and music, especially if you enjoyed the katamari series. Even after hearing the same song for a few hours, you shouldn't get sick of it unless you really hate jpop. 

For me, the game really shines in its wonderful level design and difficulty curve. The first world is quite easy and will introduce you to the mechanics without being too punishing. As the game progresses, however, you'll find that every new level is just slightly outside of your skill level - not easy but never impossible. As someone who never plays first person shooters, I never felt that a level was too difficult to complete with all 3 stars. As far as the level design, there were multiple occasions where I saw what the level wanted me to do and got giddy with excitement, completely in love with the elegance of the design. 

I can't recommend this game enough. This is a game that I will always remember fondly, and I'll probably play it again in a few years when I've forgotten the specifics of the levels.

16508291.review:
Alright- I'll be the devil's advocate here. Lovely Planet is a Quake-esque first person platformer and bullet hell shooter. People are comparing this game to Super Meat Boy, but I disagree completely. Not only that, but I think this game is shite. Here are my points:

Super Meat Boy is about precision, and tight controls. Meat Boy himself is basically a walking hitbox- he's a tiny cube that dies if he touches any enemy or any environmental obstacle, and while that insta-death aspect is true in this game, really nothing else is even close to similar to Meat Boy.

Unline Meat Boy, LP is in first-person, which is a challenge for bullet hell-style insta-death games, because traditionally the idea of a bullet hell is that you can see what's going to hit you and be able to dodge it based on your hitbox, whether it be that glwing dot on the back of your spaceship or Meat Boy's tiny, but rigidly defined body. In an FPS, however, you lose that precision. When a bullet is flying toward you, you have no clue how far you need to dodge to actually have it not hit you, which makes a lot of deaths in this game a result of shitty design rather than lack of skill. First-person view also restricts your vision- in a 2D shooter or platformer, you have all the information right in front of you, but in an FPS, you have to be constantly swiveling around, trying to see everything around you, and that restriction of your vision can be frustrating.

The same goes for the platforming- very few FPS games ever do precision platforming because it's just so shitty to pull off: in a game where you can't see your own legs and can't see your own hitbox, jumping into obstacles and getting a death can often be the result of hazy game design rather than being bad at the game, and people don't like that. People want to die because they're shitty players, not because not enough thought went into the design of the game.

Yet again, the shooting suffers from similar falling-off points: lack of clarity being the main one. I find it hard to even call this game "precision" when it doesn't even have a crosshair, and if, say, the weapon you're holding came out of your character's midsection Quake-style, then that would have been a little bit better, but no- it actually shoots at an angle to the left, making it incredibly unprecise.

Soundtrack's good enough, though- I get that what they were going for was kind of an ironic, disingenuously quirky theme to contrast with the hard gameplay, but it really just didn't do it for me.

As you can see, I haven't even played very much of this game yet- I'll admit, I've tried the first level of the second world maybe 200 times and no matter what I do, I die seemingly at complete random when I'm not close to even touching any obstacle. I'm sure it's something that the game just hasn't explained to me, and for fucks sake I don't need a completely hamfisted tutorial to understand it, but holy shit. I literally just die every time I move in any direction in the first level of the second world, and I can't get past it. And I'm not terrible at FPSes, either- the game is just so unclear that it's not fun for me at all.

(sigh)... if everything I just said made you leap to your feet and think, "finally! a game just for me!", then for fucks sake buy it, it's only six dollars. But I think it's a prime example of when a shitty game gets acclaim just because of the unique visuals and concept, instead of quality gameplay, and for a game that really does lean incredibly heavily on its gameplay, that's a very bad sign.

16266875.review:
[h1][b]TL;DR:[/b] Infuriating puzzle platformer, a less stylish 3D-version of Super Meat Boy[/h1]

Don't let this game fool you with it's name and graphics -- after playing it for an hour, you'll be furious, because you won't be able to complete some level in the 2nd zone. You'll be screaming at the game, most likely sluring a lot, yet you'll get weird feeling of a satisfaction after completing the level you've been grinding for the past 15 minutes.

There's really not much to tell about it: it's basically a fast-paced puzzle platformer with weird Japanese graphics and j-pop to pair with. As of the level design, you usually have to grind as hard as you did in Super Meat Boy to complete each zone -- you have to memorize the maneuvers and timings, time your shots and watch your step carefully; hell, late levels are a lot more hardcore than Super Meat Boy, I tell you!

Shooting 4 apples in the air simultaneously, then landing a few inches from spikes, dodging 2 shooters (shooting off their bullets with yours, then shooting them) and jumping from the disappearing platform -- all of that happening in a timespan of 1.5 seconds; that's the harsh reality of this game.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Is it worth buying? Hard to say. I'm not a fan of the genre, so I'd rather pass on it if it wasn't in a bundle. But hardcore die-a-lot puzzle platformer fans might find it interesting. So yeah, I'd recommend this game to them.

[b]Rating: [/b] 6.5 out of 10.0

16204724.review:
Lovely Planet, is indeed a lovely planet.

Its a highly fast-paced fps game action game, although at the beginning from the screenshots I was under the impression that its some sort of an adventure game like an open world and what not, but turns out its level based, and every level can be finished in 10 seconds or so, so they're all short levels and the faster you finish the more stars you earn.

[h1] My impression of the game [/h1]

I Absolutely loved the soundtrack in the game, especially the first one, it gave the game this perfect fast-paced "cute" shooter touch.

The graphics are good, fits with the game style I suppose, the enemies and the world design and all looks really adorable.

The levels are really good, and they get harder and harder as you go and to me it was almost impossible to get more than 1 star at the later stages in the game, which is good if you're into the hardcore fast challenging type game because this is really tough.

The game is easy to master, the controls are very simple and the shooting and jumping in the game is so satisfying, and the game itself is really addictive, just watch one gameplay video and if you're into this fast-paced cute stuff you'll probably buy this game before even finishing the video.

And also as you go further in the game more stuff gets added, stronger enemies and more challenging and twisting levels and platforms.

[h1] Small cons [/h1] 
I played the game in offline mode for a while then when I got my internet connection I carried on, but still did not receive the achievements, saying this because basically all the game's I played in offline mode gave achievements.

And also the achievements in the game are not really that good, just getting stars and finding secrets.


Review was a bit short, because well nothing much to say about the game, there's a reason it got so many good reviews from major reviews, because the game is just great.

So again, if you're into this type of game by watching the screenshots if you like this type of graphics, then I highly recommend you to buy it, its cheap, has cards, achievements and provides you hours of fun.

16035931.review:
Lovely Planet is a game that literally takes the phrase "Don't judge a book by its cover" to a whole new level.

On the surface the game looks cute, innocent, forgiving and would probably only be enjoyable for kids under 8.
But that's just what the developers want you to think...
This game requires a good amount of trial and error, memorization, patience, quick reflexes... and did I say patience?

Lovely Planet has one goal, you have to reach the pink beam at the end of the stage without dying or killing innocent jelly people (that also shoot back at you occasionally).
Got it? Good, because there's more to it then just that!

The game features five worlds and about 16~23 stages in each of them. When you first start out, the game's just telling you to go from point A to point B with almost no resistance in-between.
Quickly it goes from being hilariously easy to 'moderately' difficult as they introduce:
-Jelly people that shoot back (some of them you can't actually hit or you will instantly lose).
-Apples that can't hit the ground.
-Timed mines.
-Homing bullets.
-Fog that limits your vision.
-Ice that freezes you in place for a couple seconds.
-A lot of restarting....

Once you start getting into the groove of things though the game does actually get really enjoyable. Restarting will become second nature and you will probably be getting used to not knowing what's around every corner, or where every apple is falling in the stage at any given moment.

Lovely Planet gets compared a lot to games like Quake/Serious Sam with its fast-paced fps nature, Beautiful Katamari with its aesthetics, and Super Meat Boy with its emphasis on speedrunning.

The game has a beautiful soundtrack that during the frantic, heart-pounding gameplay tries to keep you calm and relaxed. All the while you're fighting back the urge to not break your mouse/keyboard (or controller) over that shot you missed that was ever-so slightly off mark on the last thing before the stage was about to end...

I'd highly recommend Lovely Planet but it is a short game, so unless you know you're going to be replaying stages for better times/stars or going for some of the achievements then just wait for a decent sale.

15937201.review:
I didn't exactly know what to expect when I first played this game, and initially it looked like an interesting time-killer when I was bored and needed to play something different. On the surface, this game begins as a fun, cute platforming FPS in which you have to reach the finish pole while also eliminating every enemy in the level, these enemies being red blobs of various shapes. Some of these enemies shoot bullets which you can parry by shooting with your own gun. Wanting to get all the achievements, I had to get 3 stars on every level, one for finishing, one for finishing quickly, and one for 100% accuracy. This was an enjoyable challenge because it kept things tense in the first few worlds as I had to aim my shots carefully and be hasty. 

The last 2 worlds, Swamp and Mountains, were a whole different story however. Homing bullets were introduced, ones that you must shoot or death is basically guaranteed. Levels became misty, and homing bullets started flying out of nowhere. Bombs that are launched and must be shot before they hit the ground or you are killed instantly involve having to gauge where the bomb will be at a certain time and shooting at that spot, which is more fun than it sounds. With all these elements combined, eventually, the game turned into one of the hardest FPS/platforming experiences I've had, at least in order to get 3 stars in every level. Due to a requirement of 100% accuracy, every shot had to count, and no excess shots were allowed. After hours of memorising and practice, I would have to progress through the level, flicking and swiping to the next target, doing 90 and 180 turns constantly in order to shoot the various obstacles in my way. Despite all this difficulty, when you finally reach that finish pole with 100% accuracy, it makes you feel like some action movie star or an aim-botter of some kind :P. While torturing and rage-inducing, the rewarding experience of succeeding in this way is unmatched, and the main reason why I recommend this game, and what makes it so enjoyable.

There are also a number of secrets in the game, which are fun to look for and find, especially the fabled "Planet Shrine" secret which is an elusive one and may require some research to be discovered.

Overall, much better than it seems on the surface, and should be played and 3 starred until the end for maximum enjoyment.

10/10

15935626.review:
Wanted to like this game, and started to, but then when I finally realized the idea behind the game and and mechanics reinforced by the design I ultimately have to say no. I'll start by saying I love the idea of the opposite setting to the gameplay; hard precision fps in a cartoon world. The characters are cute, the music is nice. I have no problem you only use a bow and shoot the game people, and the levels are pretty similar. At first I loved the game, as I found it tough but mostly fair. Most parts just took a little practice. Around world 3 and especially 4, the game really started to go in the wrong direction. I have been playing FPS games all my life and have gotten very good and have played tons of different types of ones, so I can comment pretty confidently on this. 

My first problem is the aiming. There are no crosshairs, which I would be fine with, but the shooting and aiming is off. Instead of your shots going in front of you where they should, they go off to the side and are unpredictable. You have to turn your body to shoot in front of you. They should either have included crosshairs showing where off to the side you shoot, or just had you shoot in front of you without crosshairs. I died so many times from something coming at me in the center of my screen or something I wanted to shoot, only the have the bullets go to the side, or below, or anywhere but where they should have gone. In a shooter requiring precision and timing, this is a no-no. 

There were problems with enemies. First off, there are homing shots. Now normally with a homing shot if you dodge it is misses you, and with a bullet or something it would keep going and hit into something. In this game thats not true somehow. If you dodge a homing shot, you instant die. Which means if you miss the tiny little moving thing (with the poor aiming) coming at you, you auto die and restart the level. My dodges should count, but the same makes a mistake here. Next up are the apples in the air you have to shoot. I have no problem with shooting things out of the air, but the game starts to overuse it. Instead of it at certain parts and in certain levels, the game starts having them throughout the level, and EVERY single level. They usually also use 2 at a time, and pair that with homing missiles. It just becomes annoying. This changes the gameplay. Instead of me having to make precision shots and sometimes shoot things out of the air, but also have little breaks and go at my own pace at times in between things and make levels more fair, you basically just have to keep moving forward at all times and you need to follow the developers set pace. This makes me not feel like I'm moving through the level, but I am only a roller coaster the developers made, and my only input is turning and shooting. It also makes it so even if you dodge and shoot things, if you don't keep pace or see where the apple is, you die and start over. Where before you got to enjoy yourself with the challenge, and time was for the leaderboards and tryhards, now it becomes the only thing that matters. 

The game finally comes to a head in the 4th world, where (dumbest design decision I could think of) the entire world is surrounded in fog, and you can't see ahead of you. This turns every level into you jumping not knowing what is next and where you are going. You see a ball at the last second or the homing missiles right when they are on you, taking away aiming and making it reflexes or luck. The other problem is this forces this game into the worst offense. Instead of it being skill, it becomes repetition. Because you can't see where you are going next, and every next part has a new homing missing you have to hit first try and you die, or 2 apples falling that you can't see but have to keep running forward and start shooting hopefully to hit, you have to find out from error. Every level becomes the same. You start one part, fail, repeat, figure that part out, jump into the next area without seeing whats next, keep running because you hear falling object, get there too late, start over, keep redoing all of that till you sprayed enough to kill the object, get to next part, die because you can't see whats next, die, repeat ALL of it over again, and keep doing that till you finally beat that 1 level. It becomes less based on your skill or ability to think on the fly, but slowly figuring out where each little thing is, and spending 100 tries on one level before you finally beat it. That's not good game design. I can make a boss with 150 hitpoints and you do 1 damage a hit, and you have 1 hit death and you have to start all over. People will spend hours repeating the fight till they beat him, and only a few will, but just because something requires 100 times doesn't make it well made, some people just like it because the few that want to waste their lives to try and beat it feel good about themselves after they finally do. Some of us have better things in life to do. If the game design in these later levels was well made, it would just take skill, and those of us with good aiming and everything would be able to beat it quickly and relatively easily. But spending dozens and hundreds of retries memorizing patterns and every single little thing to finally beat 1 level, isn't worth it or a sign of skilled design. And since there are no checkpoints or amount of life, and 1 hit means you have to redo everything, even if you beat a really hard part or a few in a row, and a new part you havent seen yet punishes you for doing it for the first time, you lose all of your progress, which is annoying. Also since a lot of parts require spraying and some luck, you may not be able to beat the part you did before again for a bit. Multiple parts I had to shoot an apple in the fog I couldn't see before it fell, so I had to start shooting based on memory of where it was from my last playthrough, and I wouldn't know I had been missing it until it was too late, now thats poor game design. And mix all the problems of homing, poor aiming, tons of timed apples, and the grinding memorizing gameplay, and fog, and you made me realize this isn't a game about skill or fun, its about repetition and tiny little progress after tons of repeated efforts. I'd rather find something that rewards talent more than time spent. If only the game stuck with the ideas of the first 2-3 worlds.  5.5/10.

15721029.review:
I tried giving this a fair chance while waiting for the card drops.  I don't seem to be blinded by the kawaii-vision and I've never played Katamari Damacy.  It's rather dull and shallow.  It's not really a fun world to be in, and you have to "make" your own fun, so to speak.  In the 90 minutes or so I played I got to level 4-10 and... oh boy.

This is "challenging" for the wrong reasons.  I'm a veteran FPS player and not having a crosshair just feels like a lazy handicap rather than a "feature".  Projectiles having a travel time are fine and all (even though I see them as inappropriate for a twitch/speedrun game like this), but not -that- slow, PLUS the zero crosshair.  This is the basis for my other complaint, which are the apple bombs.  You have to lead your projectiles on a moving, gravity-based sort of artillery round, and if it ever hits the ground you just die.  Immediately.

That in itself is fine and all, whatever, but when it gets to the point that you have 4 homing bullets zooming at you while your vision is greatly reduced (in the later levels) while you're jumping on platforms that you have to shoot only once to remove the hostile... ketchup blob thing but not twice or it will disintegrate, only trying to rush through all of that to shoot the two apple bombs that are already on their way down because they fired outside your vision range... it doesn't feel like a fair challenge.  It's just dumb.  I feel like they should be an occasional danger rather than nearly as common as the standard fodder enemy.

The music is passable, not bad but not my preference at all.  The sound effects are awful.  I had to turn them off because the various things that emitted high pitched screeching (akin to the "mosquito" noise) actually started to really bother me because you hear it so damn much.  Not like I was missing out on the single sound effect it made when you either died or shot something, or the single sound effect for firing your gun.  I did find out the hard way, though, that that gimped me from hearing the apple bombs fire so I knew when to hurry up, or even hinting that they were there in the first place.  In some levels I had no idea why I was dying until I blasted through things only to see the apple bombs for half a second before dying.

Got this in a humble bundle, and I sure am glad.  I'd be frustrated if I actually bought this outright for anything more than 2 bucks tops.

15124968.review:
O que dizer de Lovely Planet... gostava que houvesse um botão neutro de recomendação. A música é ótima, a ambientação também, o jogo tem potencial para ser bastante divertido e relaxante, porém alguns problemas destroem este relaxamento e deixam o jogo totalmente hardcore. Os primeiros níveis são bons, divertidos e durante algum tempo gostei muito do jogo e pensei que no final faria a análise mais positiva que pudesse!! .. mas estava enganado. O jogo vai ficando mais e mais complicado, até que chega a um mundo (o jogo divide-se por mundos, o mundo 1 é fácil, o 2 é médio e o 3 é hardcore) , onde precisas de ser um super hardcore speedrunner fps pro master pra passar aquela porra. Fica horrível e muito frustrante. Existe uma mecânica no jogo, em que umas "maçãs saltam do chão", e tens de as atingir o mais rápido possível. Caso uma delas, apenas uma, caia no chão, independentemente de onde estejas, é restart no nível imediato. (Falando no mundo 3..) Chega a uma parte onde tens de estar sempre a correr, pois estão sempre a ser lançadas maçãs, tens mais inimigos hardcore a dispararem-te, depois no mundo 3 os gajos ficam com aimbot, e os "tiros" deles perseguem-te até te atingirem, passando armadilhas, fazendo parkour... Já para não falar de que não há crosshairs, e os tiros não atingem o alvo assim que os lanças, vão devagarinho até lá chegarem.

Resumindo, não compres o jogo se fores um jogador casual, ou mesmo um comum jogador hardcore, compra isto se gostares de desafios, e tiveres muita muita paciência, caso contrário, prepara-te para dar rage.

Seriously, although this game is difficult it is at least fair. This game has absolutely nothing to offer in terms of story or character design, but what it does have is great raw gameplay with simple, yet difficult levels.

I really love taking chances with indie games. They'll either be pieces of programming garbage that a first year programming student could make better. Or, like this one, they'll be an amazing experience that takes a simple concept to its logical extreme. Just you, six buttons, a gun that shoots tiny cubes, and not a small number of relatively short, but increasingly difficult levels.

It is just hailarious how a serious looking game like Skyrim or Diablo III can be almost insultingly easy as long as you're properly equipped, but a cute, quirky, and simple game like this, Super Meat Boy, or the entirety of the Ouendan series will send your avatar to the morgue thousands of times. 

Very fun, would recommend

story gamers

WOULD RECOMMEND TO

14530498.review:
My GOTY for 2014.

Lovely Planet is the most simple kind of first person shooter you can play. It's an FPS on the surface and into the core, which is not a bad thing, it's a very good thing actually. With pastel like colors, angry squares shooting at you and a lovely upbeat soundtrack composed by Calum Bowen, Lovely Planet is a great game with everything on point.

What do you do in Lovely Planet? Well you shoot purple bullets towards other purple bullets, shapes with eyes that just stand in place and shapes with eyes that shoot homing bullets at you. And many more things you can shoot at (or be shot from). 
Most of the skill of the game comes from taking the right paths, taking them quickly while managing to avoid and shoot  "baddies". You can also "ace" (or 100%) levels by completing them under a certain time limit while not missing a shot. The game gets to a point where my brain can't handle all the things happening on screen, which makes a great practice game with a sense of triumph at the end of every level.

It also has a leaderboard, my favorite thing! Where you can see how good you are compared to strangers and your steam friends. Most of my steam friend gave up on forest, so I mostly have strangers, lovely. GO PLAY IT NOW.

Don't let the bubbly, pastel world fool you - this game is difficult.  A mixture of snapshot FPS and time-trial platformer, levels are just long enough to be manageable and rewarding, but require several attempts before you get the hang of the precise movements.

The only cons are it could've used more polish and less repetition.  The levels aren't painfully identical, but there isn't quite enough variety to win me over.  A few of the platforms could've been just slightly better placed to allow for better flow, and while the simple art style is okay, it could've been smoother.  More detail would've also helped to break the feeling of repetition.

7.8/10

A fun little game with great music and addicting gameplay, but the difficulty scale is very cruel. If you like games like Super Meatboy, this is like the First Person Shooter version.

Personally I only played the first few levels before I got frustrated and moved on, but for those first few levels, it was worth it :D

THE GOOD:
-Amazingly upbeat music! It gets you jacked and makes you want to beat it!
-Cool graphic style. It reminded me of the Katamari games :)

THE BAD:
-Difficulty scales way too quickly! You'll be moving from one level to the next, fighting more and harder enemies, then suddenly the game introduces a bomb. The bomb launches into the air once you reach a certain point in the level, if you can't shoot it in time and it touches the ground, you die and have to restart from the beginning. I found this completely killed the exciting flow the game had going and became annoying really fast, but other players might disagree and appreciate the challenge.

If you want to see some gameplay, here's my First Look
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SOcgX_slmYE

FINAL THOUGHTS:
Even though I only played the first few levels, the short time I had with Lovely Planet I really enjoyed! In the words of a friend, "This game is Kawaii!" XD

13982980.review:
I got the game as part of a recent humblebundle and would highly recommend the game to anyone who is a fan of the age old Katamari Damacy series, as any fan of the Katamari Damacy series can see that Lovely Planet takes a huge artistic inspiration from those games. 

Lovely Planet is essentially a merciless speedrunner with Japanese undertones (although it should be noted that the Developer QuickTequila is located and based in New Delhi as stated in their twitter) and a cute art style, and a nice upbeat kind of music score (created by Calum Bowen whose soundcloud and bandcamp you should check out if you enjoy the game's music). The game boils down to shooting anything that is red and/or has an angry face while navagating through a labyrinth like map that can range from easy to hard all while being timed as you compete against a leaderboard of other players who have beat the game in a certain amount of time. What makes the game difficult, enjoyable, and challenging is that the gun does not have cross hairs and that the movement of your character is enhanced (in the sense that you move fast, you jump far, and you just have an overall snappy and springy movement). The time aspect makes the game addicting as you constantly try to compete with others (the closest I've gotten is roughly 5.45 seconds to complete a map where the #10 rank for that map was 5.25 and goes down to almost 2.20 seconds for rank #1).

This has been repeated quite a few times in the reviews I've read below, but I would like to repeat them once more as they are a very accurate description of the game. Lovely Planet takes the speedrunning aspects of Supermeatboy, the springy mechanics of the Super Sam series, and the aesthetics of Katmary Damacy to create an enjoyable game for the price that is offered of $5.99. I myself bought the game in a recent humblebundle for roughly $5 with other games, but would recommend it to anyone who finds themself debating if $5.99 (or the regional equivalent) is worth the investment. If you are someone who enjoys speed running and some nostalgia from old Japanese-esque aesthetic PS2 games then Lovely Planet is worth the price.

Buf... por donde empezar? Al momento que lo ví estaba de que "y que chingados es esto?", pero aún así decidí darle una oportunidad. Y no me arrepiento de nada. Es divertido, genial, fresco y tan simple que lo divertido que sorprende. No es gráficamente atractivo a jugadores nuevos; es un 1-hit kill, y la dificultad aumenta RIDÍCULAMENTE conforme vas avanzando. lo que si llega a tocar un poco las pelotas, vendría siendo las malditam manzanas que salen volando (por ahi del nivel 8 o 9 del primer mundo aparecen unas manzanas que salen catapultadas, y si no las destruyes antes de que toquen el suelo, BAM pierdes), en sí son sencillas, pero se pone complicado cuando son mas de 3 manzanas al mismo tiempo, teniendo que esquivar disparos de enemigos por cada ángulo posible.

Al ser un juego rápido, no se recomienda jugarlo si estás acostumbrado a sentarte en una esquina, disparando a cualquiera que pase por la puerta. Otra cosa que hace al juego mas intenso, entretenido y emocionante, es la falta de una mira, así que debes tantear donde disparas, y si eres como yo que quieres tener una puntuación limpia (10 disparos hechos y 10 acertados), tendrás que disparar, birncar, esquivar y apuntar al mismo tiempo.

El soundtrack es pegajoso, simple, pero aún asi, genial. Una obra de arte asombrosa. Si me quedase dinero, sin duda compraría el OST (pero mejor lo descargo xD).

Aunque parece un juego con modelos hechos por un crío de 3 años, la simplicidad de los modelos llama la atención, hace al juego mas ameno y te distrae de juegos estilo COD, o BF. Es un juego colorido, divertido en el cual se necesita mucha destreza por lo anteriormente mencionados. Este juego sin duda requiere que tengas paciencia (te lo aseguro. morirás más de 1 vez en niveles después del 6 o 7 del primer mundo), precisión (al no tener mira, necesitarás habilidad para acertar ese disparo) y habilidad (correr, apuntar, disparar y esquivar no lo puede hacer cualquiera)

10/10, este juego me cautivo y me obligó a hacer una de las reseñas más largas que he hecho en mi vida xD. tan solo 30 minutos de juego y ya está en mis favoritos. Sin duda, algo genial que DEBERÍAS jugar :D

13918487.review:
Lovely Planet is an enigma.

On the surface, the game is cute, bright, colorful, and has one of the best produced soundtracks I've ever heard, taking major influence from J-pop and various production styles like it. It looks adorable, it feels adorable, it is adorable. 

Then you start playing it.

This game is a first person shooter that is essentially a very cute target practice sim. You need to haul it as fast as you can through various obstacles to the ending pole, shooting any and every red enemy that you see, while avoiding shooting at the blue ones. You run pretty fast, you jump very high, and you have infinite ammo in your block shooting gun. No enemies take more than one hit to kill, and only one type will shoot back at you; shooting the bullets they shoot kills them as well as stops the bullet. You have three objectives to get stars at the end of the game; beat the level (duh), beat a minimum time they give you, and have 100% accuracy on all of your shots. Sounds decently straightforward, right? That's because it is, in theory.

The first world is decently easy. However, even in this world expectations are quite high; a lot of the levels I beat the minimum time by few milliseconds, just because it's so fast paced. This might just be me being bad at the game and not being fast enough, because a lot of the world records are half the average speed. However, as angry and frustrated at both yourself and the game you get, you're never genuinely mad, because of how cute and fun the world around you is. Beat a 10 second minimum level in 9.997 seconds? That sucks, but holy sh*t this soundtrack!

The second world adds a new mechanic into the game; you need to shoot apples (tomatoes? large red bean bags?) before they hit the ground. Now, this would be very easy if your bullets had normal bullet physics; however, they move at a consist speed, about the same speed you run. So, if you need to shoot one of these things from a good distance as it's falling down, you need to aim your bullet down just above the ground so it'll collide into it. This is not as easy as it sounds, and I've had amazing runs destroyed because the apple hit the ground a few frames before the bullet hit. However, as all this difficulty stacks up and starts to become extremely frustrating, the amazing soundtrack just slowly washes it all away.

Is this game relaxing, fun, and a good takeaway from stress and other more violent and dark games? Absolutely.
Is this game frustrating, rage-inducing, and the bane of speedrunners everywhere? Absolutely.

13856171.review:
The combination of first-person shooter and precision platformer is tricky to pull off, but with the exception of one major design flaw, Lovely Planet does it pretty well. 

The first aspect of this game that stuck out to me was the minimal, pastel-color visual design. Combined with the aggressively cheery (and quite good) J-pop soundtrack, it helps mitigate that the game is (at points) ridiculously difficult--I know I would probably have lost my patience with a game of this style that insisted on being grim and gritty. But, beyond that, this kind of game just flows better with minimal environments. By stripping away most potential distractions, the path and objectives (shoot all the red things, don't shoot the blue things, get to the lavender thing) become very clear.

This is important, because Lovely Planet is a game that encourages you to move very quickly: if you stop moving, you will probably die. This can lead to a pretty rocky start, but as you get the hang of the game, you get better and better at whizzing through levels, bouncing around with your impossible levels of FPS air control and felling enemies with single shots. As such, the game's biggest strength is that its level design facilitates this kind of gameplay. The levels are quite hard, but they are constructed so that finding the right path through them is fun rather than a grind. 

One criticism I have seen leveled at the game is that the gameplay can get somewhat monotonous, but I think this is more due to the visual design than the individual levels. The environments don't change very much between worlds, which, although preserving the nicely minimal atmosphere, gets dull. Also, some of the later enemies' abilities aren't very well explained, and given that everything instantly kills, it can be kind of hard to tell what an enemy is doing the first few times it gets you. However, this doesn't weigh too much on the game compared to the one big problem:

A lot of the challenge comes from tests of accurate shooting, rather than tricky platforming jumps or constant reflex tests. This is quite a sensible approach, but it would be significantly more fun if the gun had a crosshair. As it is, it doesn't, and given that the second and third worlds are largely based around skeet-shooting of a sort (enemies that kill you if they hit the ground) and enemies with homing projectiles that you have to shoot out of the air, respectively, this adds an unnecessarily irritating learning curve to aiming. 

Still, none of this overrules the fact that the first time I started to write this review, I thought, "Wait, why am I writing about Lovely Planet when I could be playing Lovely Planet?" and stopped. Once you get the hang of aiming and jumping, it's got addictive gameplay and a nice difficulty curve, set against a pleasant and cheery background. If you're strange like me and find ultrahard trial-and-error gameplay relaxing in a way, this comes recommended; otherwise, proceed with caution.

13820763.review:
Lovely planet is a FPS frustration/perfection game (i.e. FPS Super Meat Boy, but not nearlyl as good).

The game design is not good enough, which is a shame because it does a couple of things right and I wanted a FPS SMB.
The leveldesign is very obtuse on a sizeable chunk of the levels and the game uses showing you the path via camera animations as a crutch. (Like Prince of Persia Sands of Time did, and it wasn't good back then)
The first few levels are quite easy until you get the enemies with the homing missiles, then it gets frustrating. 
The missiles have a very narrow turnradius so that you can't dodge them (which would've been fun, think of N or SMB), you have to shoot them before they reach you, there is no crosshair and aiming your shots is unintuitive (I guess they retain some of your momentum; they definitely do not behave like rockets,  thtough it's not as intuitive to aim as Tribes Ascend). 
Those enemies look exactly like previous enemies with completely different behaviour, except that they have a hat on. Same color, same shape and even the projectiles look the same!
When you fall down a ledge, there is no physics, instead of falling with the same gravity as you would had you  jumped, you get instantly teleported to the lower ground which is very jarring and can make you run into (non-homing) projectiles that you didn't even see. 
If your gun clips into enemies, you can't kill them until you back out again.
The leaderboards are full of cheaters with impossible times and unlike Dustforce, there are no replays; this leaves you with just finishing the levels like that or trying to get 3 stars by beating a preset time (which is sometimes hard but doable) and finishing the level with 100% accuracy which is both a matter of memorization and patience.

The music is upbeat, which lessens the frustration.

It's not the worst but it's sub-par.

13819962.review: Oh my...! I didn't know that I'd enjoy that game that much! Do not be fooled by the happy, bright colours. It's truly oldschool arcade FPS with a huge number of different levels that require skill in using mouse, keyboard and your own head to find out which path is the best to pass certain level. The difficult level is balanced, because you start from the easiest levels, through average ones and end on the hardest on each world. You get stars for your effort, up to 3, although this game has it's classic feel of "one more time, I can do better", which I liked the most, maybe because of nostalgia over some classic games I haven't played for years. Also, you can compare your results with your friends and see global scores (the best ones and those, which are close to your own score). Generally speaking, it is simple (but it very easy!), funny and recommendable game both for younger and older players.

You may retry the same level many times trying to get through it, but it does not feel tedious since you are thrown right back into the action. The simlicity of the graphics really tears the game down to its essential components. I have not played much yet, but I can see this being my new go to time waster.

13804981.review:
I can't say I've actually finished the game, but at this point I have to say I'm done with it. And that's only after a grand total of maybe 70 minutes of playing it. Don't let the cute aesthetic with its simple pastel colored shapes and cutesy cheerful anime music deceive you, this thing right here is about as hardcore FPS as it gets. Why? First person precision jumping levels while wielding a gun without a crosshair, that's why. You have to hit every single enemy or you can't win the level. You have to dodge every projectile because everything is a one-hit-kill. You have to shoot out apples from the sky after they're being launched from a catapult before they touch the ground, otherwise you lose the level. And for some enemies you actually have to shoot their projectiles themselves since they home in on you, before you can engage the enemies themselves. The game is hard, and I do mean hard because everything is on the clock, events constantly trigger while you're just moving forward and if you're not 100% concentrated on the game you can forget getting anywhere here. 

The game does give you some help though, at the start of any level you can preview the upcoming challenges to prepare yourself for what's to come, which is a nice feature, especially when the game at the end of a level tells you you missed an enemy and you have no goddamn clue where he was hiding. 

For all the praise I can give it for being an undiluted FPS experience that truly tests your skills as a player, there are a couple of criticisms I want to lodge at it. First and foremost, it seems like a very short game overall. They claim that there are a hundred levels in the game but after 70 minutes, my arthritic old ass that's not used to twitch shooters anymore managed to get through 75% of the levels. And that's with excessive trial and error since most levels can be beaten in a couple of seconds. So I simply have to assume that by the end of it, a more skilled player will beat the game in under say 2 hours. It doesn't cost much so I guess the price is justified, but in the end, the whole experience is just running through levels as fast as possible while taking out all the enemies and never getting hit. There's literally no story here, just obstacle course after obstacle course and it's clearly geared towards speedrunners because the game keeps time of your performance and then insults you by showing you all the assholes who managed to beat the game 5 times faster than you did. I can appreciate the game for what it is and the execution is basically perfect, but to me this isn't a game that I'll be remembering all that much because there's really no substance there. I'm the kind of gamer that likes a game to tell me a story, not just present me with some mechanics, well thought out they though may be. 

They're not asking for much cash here so I guess even though I'm not overly pleased with the game, I'll give it a recommendation for people who really want a challenging, unforgiving shooter that just might catch you off guard because of the unconventional aesthetic. Though if you want to have it a bit cheaper, there's currently a Humble Bundle offer that's definitely worth picking up so you can get it a bit cheaper.

PcGamingWiki.com/wiki/Lovely_Planet

[h1]PC Port Quality[/h1]

Basic key rebinding, doesn't detect Mouse 4/5 (Thumb Buttons). Controller has no mapping, and while it has cute icons in the environment to go with it, I wouldn't at all recommend using it because of the difficulty. Graphics options are minimal (AA, Vsync, Adjustable Frame Cap incl. Unlimited). Supports multi-monitor and all common aspect ratios if not everything. No FOV Adjustment (default is okay enough for average PC user), No Crosshair even optionally. No performance issues.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

This game is amazing, but not for the feint of heart, or for those with even average dexterity. Beyond the middle of the 3rd world, out of a total of 5, the game becomes extremely difficult, and that's even with an on-screen crosshair (built into my Asus Display), which the game completely lacks by default. Up through the 3rd world I was able to complete the 2 bonus stars for time and 100% accuracy, but beyond that point more and more levels become an immense challenge just to finish at all. In other games, if you aren't good you can beat things, but you just wont get all the points or whatever. In this, if you aren't exceptionally good, you literally will not beat the game.

More enemies, mechanics, and obstacles are added as you progress, and while most aren't portal levels of brilliant, they do a good job of mixing up how you think about different situations. Though because of the difficulty near the end, it makes it a challenge to experiment with various timings, as it puts you in situations with very little time to react and execute, though retrying from the beginning of each level is nearly instantaneous.

The controls are extremely responsive (they really need to be for the end-game), and there's more variety than you'd initially expect. Though again, you need to be good enough to even see all of it. However, once you unlock a new world, ALL of the levels are open to you instantly. You're not completely stuck if you find a level right in the middle that gives you trouble, you can come back to it later, or never at all as you only need a certain amount of stars to progress.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

The visuals are very minimal, but extremely charming in combination with the music. The game is frustrating, but the amazing music by Calum Bowen forces a smile onto your face for most of the experience. The soundtrack was free around the release of the game, and I've listened to it a considerable amount. The only thing I'd wish for, is more variety in the environments. There's definitely some there, but ones with drastically different color palettes or even nighttime levels would be a treat.

[h1]TLDR - Summary[/h1]

I completely and totally recommend it for fans of shooters both old and new. It's extremely responsive and the music and visuals just make you smile. The beginning levels are a joy and they're worth experiencing for it's common sale price. Just don't plan on seeing everything unless you're already skilled in twitch shooters, or you're willing to work at it. This was clearly made by a fan of shooters and PC gaming, and other than some small adjustments, I tremendously appreciate it.

13775614.review: Lovely Planet lives up to its name and is truly a lovely game. It reminds me of Super Meat Boy in the sense that it encourages replaying until you ace a level, and is not as frustrating as it may seem due to the great soundtrack that continues to play through deaths, quick restarts, and the real sense of accomplishment one will get once they beat a level that has been the bane of their play. I have not finished it yet, and have only finished 2 out of 5 worlds, but I am sure I will come back again and again when I need something relaxing, yet challenging to play. Which is a good point to bring up. Lovely Planet is a very relaxing game. The cutesy pastel aesthetic is one that really sets it apart from other FPS style games and combined the soundtrack backing it, makes for an almost meditative experience. Sure, there will be some moments where you feel frustrated, but every death of mine (and there are many) has felt like it is my fault. Not the game's. All in all, I can't believe this is only 5 dollars. It is a wonderful experience. One that I feel many will enjoy. If you are easily frustrated, I would say stay away, but if you are curious, go for it. I think fans of the "just one more try" games will love this. I did.

13262742.review: As many of the other reviewers are saying: Quake(FPS and movement) +Super Meat Boy (Speed and platforming) + Katamari (visuals). It's a cutesy but challenging game which will test your reflexes and memorization of patterns. Deceptively simple in the beginning, it adds more and more content as you progress, and what was simply a "bounce forward through the level shooting static enemies" experience becomes: Immediate 180 turn, forward and left past moving blob of death, bunny hop gap, shoot blob blocking landing then instantly shoot dude right in front of you, then jump onto bounce pad, then shoot a falling apple in midair, then quickly jump across three dissapearing platforms, hop over spikes, dodge shots and kill two more guys around corners, then shoot an apple with unhittable targets behind it, and finish. Then they intoduce homing projectiles and flying enemies and stuff, and the content gets really frantic. The level design retains the same aesthetics, but with small changes on each particular level, and more stage hazards as you progress. There's also a couple possible paths on most levels, and there are secrets hidden throughout the game as well. There's not a ton of motivation to find them in my opinion, but if you're an explorer then you can poke around for the achievements. The game is arcadey, and scores you based on your performance. Getting three stars for a par time and perfect accuracy for your bullet ballet feels great, although don't expect to do that past the 2nd or 3rd world. It's a good example of a videogame that comes out of left field to provide a neat experience I didn't know I was missing. It's not perfect, but it's certainly worth a look. 7.5/10

Un shooter/platformer de précision dans lequel il faut traverser de très courts niveaux en un temps record sans se faire toucher par les dizaines d'éléments qui veulent vous tuer sur le chemin. Ca commence en mode difficile mais faisable et c'est plutôt sympa, c'est coupé en 5 niveaux d'une 20aine de stages, jusqu'à la fin du niveau 3 pour les acharnés on peut encore s'amuser, les niveaux 4 et 5 deviennent vraiment trop précis pour pouvoir être finis avec autre chose que de la mémoire musculaire, donc il faut les faire en boucle jusqu'à avoir imprimé le chemin exact et les tirs exacts à faire pour atteindre l'objectif, certains trucs étant littérallement calculés pour vous niquer au dixième de seconde près, ce qui peut déclencher quelques hurlements. 
On regrettera que le jeu soit au final nettement plus basé sur la précision de vos tirs que sur la qualité de vos sauts, avec un design des niveaux pas exceptionnel. Les joueurs en recherche de difficulté horrible trouveront leur bonheur, le joueur en recherche d'un FPS classique évitera de s'infliger ça. 
Bonus sur le dernier niveau :D

12930336.review:
Lovely Planet est une très bonne petite surprise de la part de QUICKTEQUILA (aka Vidhvat Madan).

Il s'agit d'un FPS, situé dans un monde assez surnaturel avec une once de culture nipponne, qui demandera au joueur d'être rapide, précis et d'avoir de bon réflexes pour s'en sortir.
Le principe du jeu est simple, il vous suffit d'atteindre la fin du niveau en traversant tous les obstacles et ce, tout en eliminant les "méchants" (ils sont rouges et ont l'air très méchant, vous ne pouvez pas les louper) et surtout, en faisant attention à ne pas tirer sur les innocents, représentés par des personnages tout tristes gris. (vous allez apprendre à les detester, eux et leur cri, croyez moi !)

Préparez-vous à pas mal de die-and-retry, car la moindre erreur ne pardonne pas !
Heureusement, si on se loupe, il est possible de recommencer le niveau quasi-instantanément, donc pas de temps de chargement, ce qui est essentiel dans un jeu de ce type.
Les premiers niveaux pourrons vous sembler simples, très très simples même, mais par la suite, ça se compliquera beaucoup plus, donc vous risquerez de passer du temps sur un niveau, ou un obstacle en particulier et ce, même pour un joueur expérimenté...

Si vous êtes du genre à tout faire pour être le meilleur, vous pouvez tenter de battre les records mondiaux ! (bonne chance d'ailleurs, ce sera pas facile... cependant, si vous-y arrivez, faites moi signe !)

L'aspect artistique épurée, un peu étrange et surtout extrêmement coloré est assez inhabituel pour un jeu de ce type, mais fonctionne malgré tout très bien et rend le tout très agréable à regarder, une preuve comme quoi la qualité graphique n'est pas forcément proportionnelle au nombre de polygones dans un modèle 3D.
Par ailleurs, vous n'aurez pas besoin d'un machine de compétition pour faire tourner le jeu, il consomme très peu de ressources, donc la grande majorité des PC pourront faire tourner Lovely Planet sans souci.
(et honnêtement, si vous avez du mal à faire tourner ce jeu, il serai peut-être temps de changer votre machine !)

Entre autre, gros coup de coeur pour l'OST de Calum Bowen, contenant aussi bien des musiques entrainante et rythmées que des musiques plus calme et relaxantes qui correspondent parfaitement bien à l'univers un peu étrange de Lovely Planet.

Le seul point que je pourrai considérer comme "négatif" (même si ça semble plus être une préférence personnelle) est l'interface des différents menus du jeu, qui je trouve, est très "envahissante".
Je comprend qu'il s'agit uniquement de la direction artistique qui a été prise pour le jeu, mais je pense qu'il aurai été tout de même possible de faire quelque chose de plus ergonomique, en particulier pour le menu des Options.

Malgré tout, pour un prix pareil, Lovely Planet a été un excellent achat pour moi, et un jeu que je recommanderai à n'importe quel amateur d'FPS.

PS : Qui se souvient du mod DeFRaG pour Quake III ?
Personne ?
Comment ça personne ? Allons...

12810460.review:
As a person who is not at all familiar with FPSes and barely plays them, I am most certainly the best candidate for writing a review on this hardcore twitch-FPS game.

I am just absolutely in love with this game. 

I expected to enjoy it at least in the easier parts of the game, but I was not ready for how much bloody fun this little game is to play, and I did not expect how INSANE it could get. Even more insane is the fact that... yeah, I *can* deal with this. Somehow. (At least, up through world 4 as of writing)

This may be because, secretly, this game is identical to precision platformers in every way other than the basic gameplay style. Steep but smooth difficulty curve? Check. Short, but challenging and tightly-designed levels that never drag on too long? Check. Scoring system that focuses on optimization and speed? Check. Instant restarts? Check. Heavy trial-and-error based gameplay? Check. Lives counter? Haha, not in the slightest. 

It really *is* right in the same vein as precision platformers. Yet it's not the least bit frustrating. At all. I have not found myself raging at the game even once in nearly 10 hours of play (as of writing). There are a few minor instances of somewhat questionable level design (mostly in the form of apples that you have to blindly shoot in world 4, but there are only a few of those) that annoyed me, but every obstacle is overcomeable with enough practice and there's never too long of an iteration time to get back to where you messed up. The more challenging/precise a level tends to be, the shorter, too, so you don't have sudden difficulty spikes in the form of longer, mind-numbingly fast-paced levels that come out of nowhere. Everything feels smooth and natural. You approach a new level with a feeling of "how the hell am I ever going to do this" and then you beat it and have the same experience with the next level. Going back and replaying the easier levels after completing the harder levels only makes them better, too; you can completely annihlate them and feel like a champion for doing so. 

Also, did I mention how gorgeous the game is all around? Absolutely wonderful art style, fantastic soundtrack, very polished controls. It's presented wonderfully, and the cutesy wrapping hides one hell of a hardcore experience. For $6 this is a steal, I cannot think of a single negative thing to say about it and it's certainly in contention for game of the year for me.

I also wouldn't be surprised to find that I am better at FPS games than 90% of the people who've been playing triple-A titles for the past 5 years, because I doubt any of them give as intense of a training course as this game.

Now for world 5 to kick my posterior mercilessly... help...

EDIT: Post world-5 update.
So... the game gets incredibly quirky... and even more amazing... some of these levels are among my all-time favorites in any game I've ever played, haha, and the difficulty never lets up, only getting crazier. And yet... no frustration. At all. Nearly 18 hours to perfect every level and I did not get the slightest bit mad at the game. It's just... perfect, I don't know what else to say.

EDIT: I'm editing this for the steam awards thing, but, I have to say. This game is just marvellous, even two years later. I think about this game frequently, I've played it more than most any other game in my steam library, and it's the only game I've ever seriously attempted speedrunning. It's just great.

12782048.review: Lovely Planet is a first person shooter that has the most kid friendly aesthetics that I have ever seen for an FPS, but underneath the very cute-looking aesthetic it requires quake-level precision as you progress farther down the later levels. The options menu is a bit irritating to navigate because they chose to stylize it as a list to scroll up and down so you won't be able to see everything at once like most options menus on pc and the menu itself does not have full mouse control so all you can do with the mouse is to rotate your view a little bit to look at the background in a different angle and left clicking to select levels and such. As for the gameplay, it's pretty basic with one gun that has unlimited ammunition and fires as fast as you click while running through levels shooting baddies and apples from point A to point B and in order to complete a level, you need to clear out all baddies before you reach the exit, otherwise you need to restart the level. When completing a level, the game will record the time it took you to finish the level along with global leaderboards and a 3 star scoring system which does not even tell me what I'm scored on, and yes, this game is all about getting the fastest time possible. Lovely Planet is pretty much every speedrunner's dream so if you enjoy speedrunning through games, then I will recomend Lovely Planet to those who do, but if you are not much of a speedrunner, it might be a different story. I'm not much of a speedrunner myself, but I still enjoy this game for what it is so it's probably best to stop and take a minute to think about buying it and you might be entranced in the colourful world of Lovely Planet.
