12729136.review:
I am a really big fan of twitch shooters and other skill based fps.
But this game just dropped the ball somewhere...

I enjoyed the silly music and lovely surreal design of the world.
But the world never changes... It really gets repetetive after a while
because you have the same goal over and over again.

Then when the apple mechanic gets introduced, it must be the
end for every single casual player. Let me explain: There are red
apples scattered throughout your path, those apples will launch
into the air and drop back to the ground. If you do not shoot it
before it touches the ground, it will restart the level.

This may sound ok-ish but the developer used this as his main
design gimmick. You have to do 180° trickshots midair hitting
apples in a flying arc WITHOUT A GODDAMN CROSSHAIR.
Also it is extremely important to note that your shots are not
registered instantly, no your projectiles fly at snail pace forcing
you to predict movements like a young god.

Conclusion: This is a game for hardcore speedrunning fans in
the fps genre, while looking like a smartphone game... If you are
looking for casual fun do not buy this.

12602620.review:
Don't buy this if you aren't really good at FPS games in general. There are a few reasons why I say this:

1. Despite its lovely facade, the game is HARD. Small mistakes are punished instantly, resulting in the player restarting the level.

2. To add to the difficulty even more, the crosshair is nonexistant. You're only able to shoot "from the hip". Further, the gun doesn't shoot instant projectiles like many shooters. The gun shoots slow moving cubes, so you must accurately predict moving targets' paths.

3. Often, especially later in the game, there are several mission-critical targets flying around at once, and you need the presence of mind to accurately and rapidly shoot each one.

Long story short, the game is hard. Don't bother with it if you're not already reasonably good at the FPS genre.

For people who are generally competent at FPS games, this game has a lot to offer. Each level gives three stars based on your performance. The first star is just a gimme for completing the level. The second is a time star, meaning you can't just take the time to slowly aim all your shots if you want to perfect the level. The final star is for accuracy and is only awarded when you don't miss a single shot during the level. Perfecting a particularly hard level is a very rewarding experience. 

If you love FPS and love a good rewarding challenge, this game is for you.

「こんな可愛い世界観のFPSは初めて見た。子供が初めてFPSを体験するには最適かもしれない。」

このゲーム、見た目に反してかなり難易度高いです。気をつけてください。

12423496.review:
Looking back at my Steam library and my playing history, I must say I've played quite a lot of games over the past 9 months. (And suffering in school work as a result, but that's another story.) There are a lot of great games that I've played that were released just this year. It's hard to pick exactly one.

But if there was a sub-category for "Best FPS I've played that was released in 2014", it would be this one, hands-down. Why? Well...

Lovely Planet. It's as its namesake suggests. An incredibly cutesy, Japanese world with Japanese-styled characters. Everything pretty much looks like it came from some weird utopian anime with lovely planets and lovely worlds. But beneath that cute and cheery appearance lies a game that has far more depth than you would have thought it had.

For starters, despite its Japanese themes and Japanese-styled soundtrack, it was actually coded by a guy based in India. Vidhvat Madan - remember the name. I certainly would be. In terms of [url=http://vidhvat.com/][b]his games[/b][/url], Lovely Planet is the most polished one that he's come up with yet. And the soundtrack...not by a Japanese, but by UK-based Calum Bowen. Incredibly catchy, and still miles better than the turd that passes for radio pop nowadays.

You're armed with a gun that shoots purple cubes of [strike]DEATH[/strike] love, and you use it to [strike]kill[/strike] love all the red [strike]enemies[/strike] friends that you see around the map. They need your love. But don't shoot the gray ones, they already have enough, and any more than that will cause them to die from too much love. There are also a few types of fiendish traps strewn across the levels - for starters, apple bombs that trigger once you reach a certain point, you have to shoot them before they touch the ground, or else you go BOOM*! Other traps include a proximity trap which, when set off, renders a certain area unsafe after a few seconds - going into that area, uh, vapourises* you.

The first few levels start off easy, but after a while, you're involved in increasingly trickier scenarios. Take this one level for instance. I walk past an apple bomb, jump off onto a jump pad, and before I land on the jump pad the apple bomb I just walked past triggers and is launched into the air, along with ANOTHER apple bomb further along the way. You somehow have to turn around, shoot that bomb that you passed, then quickly turn back around and shoot the next bomb. All while you're probably in the air or trying to land on that jump pad. That was possibly the first level I really struggled with.

Lovely Planet's an incredibly punishing game. You have no crosshair (it feels really weird, mind you) and you have to judge your shots right. Most of the level solutions are learnt by rote - fail, fail and fail again, all while discovering how to pass some parts of the stage each time, and then perfecting the method for that one exhilaratingly perfect run. Good challenges, too - there's a speed challenge for beating a certain time, and an accuracy challenge where none of your shots go to waste. 
The game also takes cues from games like Super Meat Boy - respawns are near-instantaneous so you don't have to wait too long to try again. Because you'll be trying again and again a lot of times.

I've been notoriously bad at FPS games, so I don't forsee myself being able to complete this one, unfortunately. But even if I didn't, I'd be damned if I claimed I didn't have fun with it.


Oh, and before I end off: I like reading PC Gamer Reviews because their writers have a masterful command of English. For the most part, I agree with them. However, I'm going to go out on a limb here and say I disagree with [url=http://www.pcgamer.com/lovely-planet-review/][b]this particular one[/b][/url]. The presentation, contrary to what they say, is NOT MEDIOCRE. In fact, it's perfectly appropriate for this game. Not every FPS must look like CoD or Crysis. 

I will concede though that they at least gave one of the better scores. Other critics don't appear to like it as much, and that's a real shame, because this is such a...wait for it...[i]lovely[/i] gem. Okay, okay, I'm sorry, I'll stop now.


[h1]When to buy[/h1]
If you're into FPS games, you'll probably enjoy this, it might be worth full price to you then. If you're into FPS games with a large modicum of seriousness...put that all aside and get this. Don't be serious for a change.
If you're not either of the two, it's been bundled at least once so try trading for a key.

[h1]Other games from the same dev[/h1]
This feels mechanically different than the first game, but is still quite fun.
http://store.steampowered.com/app/436000/

[h1][b]9.0/10[/b][/h1]

*[i]For dramatic effect only. The game isn't really that scary. Far from it, actually.[/i]

[i]This game was previously demoed on the Who's Gaming Now?! [url=http://www.twitch.tv/whosgamingnow]Twitch Channel[/url]. We regularly demo indie games on the channel, consider tossing us a follow.[/i]

12374896.review: Thanks to Rock Lee Smith I saw this little charmer and when I got around to my steam playable device (SPD) it occured to me it might be worth the 5 buck to pick up. First the game is made of every j-pop fantasy the nineties could muster. Its like Keita Takashi's design seinsibility with Jumping Flash's music in a world so symbolic it can only be parody. That said it's not a vertigo introducing exploration platformer like Jumping Flash was, rather is a simplified run and gun FPS with mild platforming elements and a lot of twitch gameplay. Not as demanding as Hotline Miami, but the premise shoot, dodge, jump, react is simple enough you get straight into flow. Being in flow is a good thing. Flow is like when the Harlem Globetrotters made a 3 point shot from inside your cranuim as you eat  a hot dog. The game disurpts Japanese mascot culture with a neo-psychedlic style reminiscent of Harajku fruits. The levels are small and bite size meaning the game is neo-arcade and like Hotline requires a bit of replay. However it never tried my patience... so far. even with a slightly buggy copy cat ps2 controller and a somewhat buggy laptop trackpad however that said the trackpad doesn't register numerous LMBs in game for some reason making the firing mechanism a tad frustrating, but easily solvable. I am only 6 levels in, but its a joyful shot of adrenaline and a lot of fun to play.

12296673.review:
It's okay. Nowhere near as fun as quake live's race gamemode. It's kind of different from that, but with less depth, with the former being about movement+precision aiming (rocket jumps etc.) and this game being ONLY about precision aiming. The movement in this game is not very good. Walking down a slope will just make you instantly slide down it, way faster than you floating down from jumping.

I don't know why a game entirely about precision aiming has no crosshair. Just because the projectiles inherit momentum doesn't make a crosshair useless. All removing the crosshair does is add guesswork to the game, which is stupid when most levels have very small frame windows in which to shoot homing projectiles. The stupidity multiplies whenever said projectiles are waiting for you in front of a teleporter exit. 

That being said I think most people could find enjoyment out of the first 3 worlds since their less cheesy and actually give you some freedom of how you complete the levels. The swamp (4th world) levels are filled with guess-working tiny windows of opportunity, and guessing where the falling apples(?) are going to be when your screen is entirely fog and you have no depth perception. Mountain (5th world) has even more homing missile spam in-front of you as you leave a teleporter. Not very fun or exciting, but the main point of saying all of this is that there's no freedom in how you execute these things. There's no discovery on what the most optimal route is, or how to do it.

The music is alright. The visuals are alright but they feel a bit lazy. They're not bad and their artistic talent is still there,  it just looks like the developers could do better.

每个场景20关，没关就是呆着一把弓箭往前冲。误射到友方人员（那种黑色的囧脸），被敌人（红色囧脸）的子弹打中，碰到红色气球，天上掉下的红色气球落地之前没有打爆，掉下悬崖，或者有遗漏的敌人没有解决就直接过关，都会被送回到起点从头开始。确保以上情况没有发生，冲到关底触碰紫色旗杆就能过关。路上还有那种蓝色的悬空石头，站上去一小段时间就会掉下来的，必须马上跳开，而且要保证自己的弓箭不会打碎这种石头，否则没有路可走也要从头开始。过关时间的长短，可以在游戏排名榜上看到。

NPC的形象，音乐都很可爱，算是扣了题目。总之茶余饭后不放轻松一下，也不用抱有太大的期望。

12078729.review:
Super Meat Boy: First Person Shooter Edition. This is how I can most accurately sum up Lovely Planet. Fast reflexes, intricately designed bite-sized stages that will sometimes take forever to figure out, and a real sense of "just one more try" are the three strong points that Lovely Planet relies on, and for the most part it handles them very well.  

Each stage of the game lasts about 20-30 seconds (if that, in most cases) and is an obstacle course you must find your way through without ever falling off of the level or being hit by various obstacles or enemy "bullets."  Lovely Planet doesn't rely on tracers or hitscan to determine if you or enemies were hit. Bullets exist in the world and travel at varying speeds and this is something you'll need to be highly aware of and learn to adapt to if you're more used to modern FPS offerings. In fact, leading your and your enemies' shots is highly important the further you progress into the game. Old school Quake and Unreal players will probably feel right at home almost instantly. 

Lovely Planet takes a pretty harsh difficulty jump once you hit world 3 and it only keeps getting harder from there. Some may really reach a point where they've hit their skill limit with how accuracy based so many of the challenges are near the end of the game. The game also introduces a fog effect later that can make obstacles like homing bullets start to feel really unfair and cheap when you have to sacrifice multiple tries in order to find out where the shots are even coming from.  

Aside from the slightly lopsided difficulty, Lovely Planet is a solid "masocore" shooter with a fun and cute aesthetic married to  a rock solid set of simple to grasp mechanics.

11896947.review:
More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

With friendly environments, pleasant music, and bad guys that look like they just need a hug, Lovely Planet isn’t your usual FPS. Lovely Planet leans more on the challenge and precision of a 100% speedrun attempt side of things. If you’re going through the game just to play it, it can still be as frustrating as trying for the perfect run.

Lovely Planet is nice enough to give you unlimited ammo and infinite lives. Let’s say you want to go for a perfect 3-star run. First off, you need to get it done fast. While you’re getting it done fast, you’ll also need to work on your shooting. While you have all of the ammo in the world at your disposal, you are dinged for poor aim. You’ll need to work on the motto of a sniper with the “one shot, one kill” thought process. You may want to work on your platforming skills as well since there is a lot of jumping in Lovely Planet too.

If you’re just looking to do a simple romp though the game, you’re still up for a challenge. The game starts to place bad guys around corners or put a few of them with itchy trigger fingers all looking and waiting for you to come out of a door. The jumps can be a little difficult as well since the jumping is almost so precise that it feels a little too strong. It takes some getting used to because most games have been focusing on realism and all of a sudden Lovely Planet says, “jumping should be more fun!”

Score: Meh...

While the “Meh…” rating may feel a little harsh, it just accurately reflects what this game makes me feel. I realize that it will be around the $6 mark, but even still I can’t say it’s personally worth it. If you’re looking for something to speedrun and set world records against the Steam community or just want to have a tutorial in FPS mechanics, then you may find some enjoyment here. If not, I would say not to bother. It’s got the depth of an Angry Birds game with better gun mechanics than some modern FPS and that’s about it. I’m not sure if this feeling is what they were aiming for, but if it was they nailed it on the head. At the same time it’s just not for me. I’d probably recommend picking it up for around $1 for a time-killer app, but anything more than that just seems excessive.

11764443.review:
Alright, so I would give this game an 8/10 at most, but there are still a lot of things wrong with it.

Let's start off with what the game is.

Lovely planet is basically an first-person shooter where you are trying to get to the end of the level as fast as you can while shooting all the enemies, and avoiding any other obstacles. The game starts off easy, and dying is quite forgiving. Every level has a maximum yield of three stars; One for beating the level, another for beating it within a time limit, and one for having 100% accuracy.

As the game progresses, you will most likely find yourself redoing levels over and over and over because you missed a shot, or you weren't quick enough causing you to not get all three stars. There are basic mechanics in the beginning, and as the game progresses, there are much more complex ones. It really tries to teach you how to play the game during the whole game without too much obvious tips.

Now for the bad of the game.

Sadly, the game doesn't feel as if it is made with all the effort the developer could have put into it. The first thing you will find is that the game doesnt have settings to change mouse sensitivity, or even a way to rebind keys. There is also no cross hair for your gun, which can be frustrating considering you are striving for that 100% accuracy. There isn't much else to do after the game is done, making this game pretty straightforward to complete. 

If you are looking for a game to just try and complete without any worry of how many lives you have, or if you just want to try and challenge yourself by completing every level, this is a good game for you. It has a ton of secrets in it, and the achievements work just fine. If you don't like games that can be frustrating, or games that have no storyline whatsoever, then I would recommend looking for another game. This game has a casual feel to it, but it feels a lot like a bullet hell type of casual fps.

This game is as difficult as it is lovely, and it's pretty fucking lovely.

It starts out very simple, doing an excellent job of teaching you the basics of the game. The movement, jumping, and gunplay are all very tight and satisfying. Then you enter world 2. And there are spikes, and jump pads, and apples you have to shoot before they hit the ground. And you'll think you know what I was talking about it being difficult.

Great game, though. Easily worth $6.

11647662.review:
This, the quirkiest and indiest of shooters, is a wonderful emotional roller coaster that picks you up as soon as it puts you down. A Super Meat Boy-like twitch FPS with the artstyle of Katamari Damacy, it is a happy, deppressing, and angry game with hours of gameplay. The baddies explode into hearts when you kill them, the flowers on the grass are just little hearts, and dying causes you to respawn in a fluffy burst of blue stars. The music and the pastel color scheme are also among the many things about this game that are on the same tier of happy as the cutest of cat videos. 

Then you get to world 2. Hell freezes over and you begin to lose your way. Fragments of your soul disappear each time you die and restart a level. You kill the same baddies countless times. Time ceases flowing as you enter a purgatorial state of mind, begging for everything to just end. You die before the end goal and stall in introspection. You begin questioning your entire life, everything you have done that let you to this game, to wish for success at every attempt and have your hopes crushed in an endless cycle.

But as you come back out of your mind, you see that the game is still there on the monitor before you. You hear that music is still playing, hearts are still fluttering, and a curious, pastel-banded planet still floats in the background. You press on through the weaboo-imagined landscape, happy as ever, as if no mind trip ever happened. Repeat this cycle until you either quit the game or amputate your middle finger from perpetually holding down the 'W' key.

Best emotional roller coaster 2014.

11644206.review: This game will eat your soul

11633344.review:
To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it sometimes made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page.

Gameplay: Lovely Planet is a game that can most easily be described as, "You got Super Meat Boy in my FPS!" The level design largely reflects on Super Meat Boy's level design ethos in that levels are pretty short, typically lasting around 15-20 seconds, but are packed with plenty of obstacles to make things challenging. These obstacles range from friendlies that you can't shoot or else you'll end the level, apple launchers in which you have to shoot the apples before they hit the ground, baddies that can shoot homing shots which you have to shoot out of the air (don't worry, it's a lot easier than it sounds), as well as plenty of other obstacles. Worlds one through three are quite a bit of fun; in fact, there was really only one level that I didn't like out of these first 62 levels.

Then comes World 4. I'm just gonna be blunt; World 4 is stage memorization central. Why? First and foremost on the bad design checklist is thick fog. Seriously, designers, limiting the player's vision is not a good way to create challenge; it's just a quick path to frustrating the player. There's also plenty of points in this world where you pretty much have to take shots in the dark to be able to complete the level (See Level 4-20 which the designers had to be high to think was a good idea). Whenever you consider that a condition for completion of the game is 100% accuracy on all stages, this really becomes one hell of a frustrating experience. Second on the bad idea checklist for world 4 are shots that literally come out of nowhere. No, that's not just the fog fooling you; these shots literally come out of thin air (obscured by the fog, of course), and you can't see them when you look forward at the stage before attempting it. The only saving grace for the average player is that these stages are among the shortest in the game, but for the completionists, this can be the worst world, as some of the par times are [i]ridiculously[/i] strict. Worlds one through three took me 30 minutes, 50 minutes, and 60 minutes to complete respectively. World four took over three hours and even then I didn't 100% the world.  As for world five... world four has put me off too heavily for me to want to play the game anymore right now. Maybe in a couple of months.

Maybe world five will be the big comeback from world four. I sure hope so. Again, worlds one through three were excellent, save for that one stage. It's just too bad about world four. 7/10.

Story: Not really any here, so I'm not gonna bother going into detail about it.

Graphics: The game sure does look great; at least, until world four where everything becomes terrible and fog. Man, though; world four really is an absolute blight on this game in nearly every respect (even in music, but I'll get to that later). But anyways, at least for the worlds that are actually good, the game really does look great. It's certainly a game that'll look great ten, maybe even twenty years down the line. You can't say that for a lot of games. As for the technical aspects, the game says that it runs at a solid 60FPS, and I can verify that it does indeed run at a solid 60FPS. No lag spots whatsoever. Also, thanks to the simplistic nature of the graphics, you can run this on pretty modest hardware. So yeah, the graphics side of the game was definitely not a disappointment. 5/5.

Sound: Only the OST to talk about here, and - *sigh* - yes, the world four song is the weakest of the bunch. Apart from that, the OST is excellent. Calum Bowen sure did a great job with this one. The tracks are sort of like if you mixed Ape Escape's OST with any Katamari OST. Very catchy, very quirky, and just very good. As for the sound design, it uses Engine of Whimsy +10. Good stuff. 5/5.

Overall scores are: 7/0/5/5; 8.5/10. Man, if it weren't for world four, gameplay would get a 9/10. Everything just went so far downhill in that world. Oh well; I'll be editing this review later on when I play world five, so maybe it'll give it a shot in the arm to bring it up to 8 or something. As for now, my advice is to play worlds one through three and then stop.

11628483.review:
This is -- beyond a reasonable doubt -- a hidden treasure among video games.  I haven't been this engaged and had this much fun with a video game in a long time.  It's very challenging while not being relentless.  As far as FPS games go, it's pretty different from anything else out there.  The goal of each level is to shoot all the enemies (and certain objects) that are strategically placed throughout the course all in one go.  There are no checkpoints.  If you die, you start the level over.  Completing the level with proficient time and gun accuracy awards you with an extra star.  The game's difficulty increases at a moderate pace and each level offers a unique challenge.  New game mechanics are thrown in at certain points along with new enemies.  You may get stuck on a level now and then but you don't feel hopeless.  You learn from each failure and feel like you are improving as a player.  The gameplay is complimented by the visuals which manage to be quirky and charming all while being extremely simple.  The music fits right along with the art style with an upbeat tempo that puts you in a good mood.

Most AAA titles these days have not given me the amount of enjoyment I've gotten from this game.  And those games cost roughly 5 to 10 times more than this one!  I honestly would have spent 20 dollars for this game. It's a steal for the price.

Try this game.  It's hard no to fall in love with it.

[b]Lovely is the perfect adjective for this game.[/b]
A very solid indie game with a simple yet fun premise, get to the goal really fast and kill all the enemies while doing so. 
This game is heaven for fans of fast FPS gameplay involving precise timed shooting, it starts simple but levels become more difficult and complex as you go along, the last two worlds are notably challenging but incredibly rewarding to complete.
The game ofsets the challenging areana shooter-esque gameplay with a cute pastel tone aesthetic which is pleasing to the eye and genuinely very fun to run through, this aesthetic is completed with a charming soundtrack which makes me think of music from the Katamari series. The tunes feature wide range of musical styles with a distinct taste of j-pop for auditory bliss, it is very hard to get mad at a difficult level with this soundtrack playing over your failure.
Lastly the game's price is extremely fair, too often you come by indie games with a large price tag but this game hits the sweet spot.[b] It is definitely worth a buy![/b]

11588715.review:
Quake＋タイムアタック＝異次元のヤブサメ

[h1][u]概要と雑感[/u][/h1]
　FPS。野を駆け、丘を飛び越え、的当てしながらゴールを目指すタイムアタックゲーム。塊魂に似たカラフルで抽象的な世界とキャッチーで可愛い音楽が目と耳を楽しませる。またあちこちに散らされたヘンテコな日本語も奇怪で微笑ましい。

　[u]日本語非サポート＋有志翻訳なし（驚いたか、和ゲーじゃない）[/u]。英語はせいぜいオプションの設定に必要になるだけなので警戒する必要なし。日本語の文字をかたどった物体が散見するが所詮は意味を持たない無機的な置き物である。

　プレイングは Quake 等のスポーツ系 FPS には劣るがそれに近いスピードで、とにかくジャンプ & ショットで動き回るダイナミックさがある。１マップ１マップが長くても数１０秒程度でクリアできるので、試行錯誤が苦にならないのも良い。

　他面、FPS 慣れしていない方にはハードルが高く、さらにクロスヘアが無いハードコア仕様なのでご用心。というかステージ２以降から FPS 慣れしていようがムズい。見た目にだまされてはいけない。

　武器は名状しがたい棒状のセミオートライフル１丁のみ。弾は即着弾ではない（いわゆる [i]projectile[/i]）上に速度が遅い。ステージの難易度が高まってくると的も一筋縄では当てられなくなり、偏差撃ちといったある程度の計算が必要になる面白みが出てくる。

　的はたいてい動かない。即死の唾を吐いてくる曲者がいたりとか、打ち上げられるリンゴの的があったりとか例外はあるものの基本的にはそうである。また撃ったらゲームオーバーの“味方”という迷惑千万な的もある。

　[strike]ところでここで「的」と呼ぶモノはリンゴを除いて実は生き物である。ヨウカンのように箱型だったり、菓子楊枝のように細長かったりするそれらはどれも胴部・四肢がなく頭部だけなのだが、撃てばうめきを上げるし確かに息づく生き物なのだ。[/strike]

　閑話休題。

　気になる点を挙げれば、[list][*]クロスヘアが無い。[*][strike]メインメニューの操作がわずらわしい[/strike]。大分改善されました！[*]マウス感度の変更がプレイ中に出来ない（数値で設定なのは◎）。[*]例のごとくグローバルランキングが無法地帯。[/list]ぐらいだ。

　ビュンビュン進み、ピョンピョン跳びながら、スタイリッシュに的当て。本ゲームはきっとあなたに根拠のない高揚感をもたらしてくれるだろう。

11569403.review:
The most amazing fps (first person shooter) to this date that I have ever played. 

If you are looking for a military shooter, it's not this. 

If you are looking for a multiplayer game to shoot your friends, it's not this.

Who ever is left and is wondering what lovely planet is. The answer is that it is the most hardcore intense shooter ever created and one of the most colorful and cheerful atmospheres I have ever had the privledge to play in. 

So what, I could just boot up TF2 and go to some unofficial server and do the same thing but with my little pony. 
Well, If you are not a brony, (or are) this game is just as effervescent. 

Ok so what if it is cute. You said it was the "most hardcore intense shooter ever".
In most military/hardcore shooters there is no hud (heads up display). This lack of a retical or something to guess where your bullets will go adds a unique level of challenge to this fps.

Whoopdedoo theres no hud, that all you got.
Well no actually, this game is timed and the goal is to get 3 stars.

Stars?
Yes, the stars are awarded upon three criteria. First that you completed the level (blue star). Second that you did it in a reasonable time (green star). Third that you had perfect accuracy (yellow star), which can be dificult considering that you have no retical to aim with.

Ok there is nothing left to do after I finish all three stars?
Wrong, if you by some arcane magic manage to finish all of the levels with three stars you can shoot for the world record on the levels. 

And after that?
Ascend to godhood.

I whole heartedly recomend this game.

11534955.review:
You want a shooter that requires oodles of skill and speed, where any little mistake will cost you and every single move counts? It's here.

The concept is simple - kill all enemies, get to the end. Mastering it is another matter. Blasting your way through the levels is extremely fun and addicting. Every shot and movement means life or death in [i]Lovely Planet[/i], yet at no point does the game seem too unforgiving or sadistic. Nailing the moves needed to pass a level feels absolutely epic, whilst trying to find shortcuts to get quicker is uttely compelling and addicting. In terms of content, there are more than enough levels to go through, with plenty of secrets and new enemies to come across along the way.

The graphics and soundtrack may not be to everyones taste, but they work to make a fully engrossing experience. It makes a refreshing change from the grim, darker colours used in the majority of other shooters giving the game a rather different yet fun feeling. There was always the risk of seeming pretentious or contrived when going for a derivative art style but [i]Lovely Planet[/i] seems to nail it.

Do I recommend it? Most definitely. If you like fast-paced games, shooters or platformers in general, get it now. It is hard to think of what better to buy at this price.

Have you wanted to know how it felt to be on drugs, but you don't want to stain your pure being? Well, look no further. This game will get you more addicted than any drug out there, guaranteed. Colors, pew pew pews, killing baddies, what else? Well, shooting immobile things has never been such a challenge. Wanna play the game casually? That's fine! Wanna take it a step further and go mach speed to earn world records? Go for it! I feel llike the game has an insane amount of replayability due to the fact that despite the levels being quote-on-quote linear, you can basically take your own route to complete them. The only requirements are that you kill every single baddie and not necessarily in a specific order, so you're free to develop strategies to complete any level as fast as possible. Even if the game looks very primitive and simple, it's challenging and rewarding. I've spent around 3 hours and reset around 500 times to get the world record on 1-5 and that's a rather simple level. It gets much, much tougher (I'm looking at you, apples.) and levels get longer, so if you're going for that WR, you'll have to get some extra patience, because you're going to see the words "Look ahead" and "Start" many, many times. So go on, get this game. I'll give a cookie to the person who'll be able to beat me on my WRs (1-2, 1-5 and 1-4). Hopefully we'll get leaderboards soon!

P.S This is a message to the person who got WR on 1-3 ... How?!

11523178.review:
For 6 bucks, or 5 on sale right now, you really can't get more bang for your buck. I've already put 5 hours into this game and barely gotten halfway through it. What's the best way to describe it? An FPS Puzzle/speedrun game? This is a game about shooting weird square enemies and other crazy looking stuff in the face with precision and speed, all the while incorporating platforming and twitch reflexes. And you do this listening to one of the greatest videogame soundtracks I've heard in years, it's very reminiscent of Katamari Damacy. In fact, the aesthetic of this game has already been compared to Katamari Damacy many times, and I totally agree with it.
It's weird, it's quirky, it's challenging as hell and it will punish you for the slightest mistake if you're going for all the stars in a certain level, but you'll also just keep coming back. This is 'just one more try' in it's purest form. The game appears to have about 100 levels and has a pretty balanced learning curve; if you're a perfectionist, getting all the stars in this game is gonna take quite some time.
I have to say when I saw video of someone playing this it didn't blow me away. This is DEFINITELY the type of game you have to play for yourself to see what's so great about it. It's bliss. When you finally get the perfect run, it's like entering a zen state. You'll just have to fight through many many many restarts and cursing at the game to get there. But trust me, it's worth it. 
One of the best indie games to come out in a long time.

11522424.review:
Lovely Planet has far more depth behind it than its flat, colorful palette suggests. An FPS dedicated more towards movement than killing, the objective is to get to the end of each stage as quickly as possible while shooting all the baddies with your star gun, avoiding all the red things that could kill you and more. There's a pretty clear path through each stage yet it seems each (if not all) have easily missed shortcuts and other tricks that shave seconds off each run. Its frantic, restart-as-soon-as-you-miss mechanics works so well in reinforcing the drive to improve your time. Each group of stages introduces new mechanics gradually but in a way that challenges without becoming frustrating. Of course, these mechanics compound in the later stages becoming downright sadistic at points. 

I'm disappointed by the lack of leaderboards as the world record just doesn't give nearly enough motivation to improve. The movement is also a bit floaty and takes some getting used to if you're more familar with Source movement but it's consistent throughout. 

Totally worth the $6.

11512706.review:
This game needs more exposure. It's an addictive FPS where the objective is to shoot every baddie in the level and complete it as fast as possible all while bunny hopping across the treacherous terrain like a maniac. The levels typically can be completed in about 20 seconds and this is where the game taps into the same nerve for efficiency as Super Meat Boy, where you'll complete a level and say "I didn't do that well enough" and do it again. You'll be rated on both time of completion and accuracy and the game continuously brings in bombastic, insane mechanics such as apples that launch into the air and cause an instant fail if they aren't shot before reaching the ground. It's brutal in difficulty as everything is a one hit kill, but entirely fair.

Counteracting the absolute insanity of flying apples and projectiles is the aesthetic. It seems indie devs are starting to move onto turning the low poly graphics of the 90s into a visual style much in the same way as 16 and 8 bit graphics have been. The closest game I can compare this to visually is the Katamari series. Everything has a quirky, colourful aesthetic to it with delightful bouncy music by Bo En. This is a world made out of origami floating inside a PS1 while you're on LSD and it's absolutely amazing. Best of all, it will run on pretty much anything.

This game is extremely cheap and if you're a fan of FPS games and want something different, you'd be a fool for not picking this up.

It doesnt even matter that the game is really cute and has some great music from calum bowen, the game itself is very solid. Play it! 

Yup, I think I can stop writing now. Those two words sum it up. Oh? You want to know why?

[url]http://youtu.be/2cizOpJycc8[/url]

Fine! So Lovely Planet; just what is this bizarre looking, and named game? In simple terms, it’s a time trial first-person-shooter, with amazing music. 

Many might get all giddy over the colours, and yes, the game is certainly colourful. Employing soft pastel-like colours up the hooha. 
Personally I think it’s the music that makes this game. It’s beautiful, fun, energetic; and it makes you want to go faster, play more and just had a very good time.
The music is simply amazingly, I just can’t get enough of it. As I play, I want more, I need to get more, so I need to play more, get deeper into the game and keep on going.

It’s somewhat faced paced, while remaining delightful, and this is exemplified by the fact that the game runs really well. It’s fast paced, smooth, and will wreak havoc on you if you twitch with a sensitive mouse.

The developers claim it’s designed for 60fps, and they’re certainly telling the truth. The mechanics, and gameplay need to be smooth and respond to reactions well.

In the game you just have to save the lovely planet from some nasty buggers. Who all happen to be pink. How dare such a colour invade and disrupt the harmony of this lovely world!
Eliminate them; all. With your trust semi-automatic block thrower, as you run and ballet jump over obstacles and deadly pink goo.

There isn’t much else to say, I simply enjoy this game. I suck at it, horribly so. Yet I enjoy it.
The colours, music, and gameplay mechanics blend together really well and leads to an enormously enjoyable experience.

Just play it, buy it and play it. It’s just so darn fun.

11399465.review:
The world is kind of a heavy place lately, and it's become hard to escape and find that moment of peace we all could really use. Everywhere we look for entertainment or relaxation reminds us of the discord and disorder seen more and more through images of violence and confrontation. Where do you turn when you want to get away from the realities of the world we're being reminded of every day?

Of course everyone enjoys the challenge and hyperactive action of first person shooters but as some of us grow older we tire of their melodramatic, heavy handed, and needlessly intense nature. Could it be possible to have that same action in a more refined, artistic, and abstract style? [i]Lovely Planet[/i] is exactly the kind of shooter to bring us this sort of peace so needed in an entertainment industry fueled by glorified aggression.

Like a series of condensed blasts of [i]Unreal Tournament[/i]'s frantic chaos rolled up into a [i]Katamari Damacy[/i] world of simple origami aesthetics and uplifting pop-folk melody, this is definitely a game for the open minded.

[i]Lovely Planet[/i] has a very esoteric and eastern feel to it with it's outgoing style and upbeat pop melodies composed by multi-talented musician Calum Bowen, giving me nuances of saturday mornings as a youth watching Japanese children's programming on old VHS my Grandparents would tape and mail. While this is obviously a very personal feeling of nostalgia, there's a different form of it each player will end up discovering in their own way and tied somehow to their own past. If that reminiscent feeling isn't there for the player initially, it will be a new memory engraved into their mind in the same way our favorite things as a child stick with us.

Despite the heavy Japanese overtones from the bits of stylized text and the simplicity of it's cute and attractive design, the game was actually created by Delhi based QUICKTEQUILA and the bridging between cultures by this up-and-coming developer gives the surreal nature of it's atmosphere a touch of authenticity.

Beginning your journey into this [i]Lovely Planet[/i] is almost overwhelming, assaulted with bright and stupefyingly cheerful audiovisuals. You're presented to an abstract world of random and seemingly unrelated trinkets and collage of colorful shapes,  sitting somewhere between the mysterious indie charm of [i]Proteus[/i] and the otherworldly grandiose of [i]Katamari Damacy[/i].

Although the attractive and charming visuals may ease you into a false sense of ease and comfort, the game is no pushover. It features a very progressive learning curve that keeps you on your toes and constantly alert. The stages require finesse as you dance around a well choreographed ballet of bullets.

The first world titled simply 'City' gets you into the motions with some short and mostly linear pathways sprinkled with some adorable visual design through bright colors, odd decorations, and an onslaught of peculiar words and phrases in Japanese strewn about. Beating this first handful of levels is a lightning quick affair where each attempt will be over before you even realize it, leaving you craving the next hit of fast paced shooting and jumping action.

This pace quickly changes as you enter the second world and on as the levels begin to twist and turn into more complex patterns. Different enemies and obstacles appear forcing you to think quicker before every jump or turn of a corner, and new increasingly peculiar tasks become prevalent from protecting your distressed looking blue companions to shooting down cartoonish apples before they plummet to the ground. The obstacle-course like stages just get harder and harder, you'll begin retrying more and more, and you'll slowly become consumed in the competitive spirit of the World Records shown at the end of each stage.

[i]Lovely Planet[/i] will cause you to wear out your restart key as you mash it mercilessly to conquer that one seemingly simple stage and in good time. You'll eventually beat these difficult and meticulously planned later levels and instantly get a feeling of satisfaction, which quickly turns into the crush of defeat as you're shown a world record only to realize you are still seconds from being the best.

[b][i]Lovely Planet[/i] is a game with roots in culture, art, and the essence of what 'fun' used to stand for. It proves that art games don't need to all have the same boring or pretentious gameplay, and can be just as engaging and fun as anything else out there.[/b]

11395661.review: In some parallel universe where FPS games arose out of cute pastel platformers with geometric shapes and dodgable projectiles (instead of shooting monsters and zombies with chain guns while collecting key cards), this would be that genre's Super Mario Brothers.  It would be the game we all adoringly remember as teaching us all the basic mechanics of the FPS.  Somehow a game I never played before is making me nostalgic for a past that never existed.  If you have kids who wants to learn to play shooter games with you or their older siblings, start this game up and pass them the controller.  It will teach them the same way that solitaire taught your grandmother to use a mouse.

11381362.review:
Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

Let me paint you a picture. I'm sitting in my living room playing “Lovely Planet” for review purposes and junk. It's pretty adorable; that's my first impression. I'm running around a world that could easily be confused with “Katamari Damacy,” shooting little red squares and pins, rushing to reach the pink and purple flagpole that signifies the end of each short burst of a level. With every victory I'm shown my time, accuracy, and the stars I've earned. I finish each level in a few seconds... at first. 

As I progress this cute little game takes a sinister turn. Suddenly I have to deal with innocent geometric dudes I can't shoot, platforms that disappear should I linger a moment too long, and giant apples I have to shoot before they hit the ground - all while bouncing and dodging (and screaming curse words so vile and bizarre that they haven't been conjured up, not in this plane of existence, anyway. Only in “Lovely Planet”).

Remember that level in “Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare?” I think it was called “Mile High Club” or something punny. Yeah, this whole damn game is that level. There are no screw ups, no second chances. I've never clutched a controller so tightly, a fact made all the more disturbing because I'm playing a game with a color scheme straight out of the Teletubby-verse. 

Those with weak constitutions should avoid this title as the catchy music and rainbow explosion background will literally drive you to slavering madness as it mocks you; taunts you. You'll replay any given level a dozen times, each death increasingly unfair to you. Your shouts of disbelief will slowly transform into maniacal, sobbing laughter as you come to realize you're the devil and sinner in this Kafkaesque Hell of your own making. And finally, with victory nearly in your desperate, grasping reach, your sweat-slicked hands will betray you and you'll fall to your death. 

And then you'll click retry. "Lovely Planet" is endearing, unapologetic in its challenge, and fun to play. This game has heart and charm usually absent in your standard 'tough as nails' fare, and it is a refreshing change of pace. For twitch gameplay enthusiasts and fans of the wonderfully weird, I can't recommend "Lovely Planet" enough.

11370670.review:
Having played the game up until the first level of the second world, here's what I have to say:

I have no idea what the story is,
I have no idea why I'm doing what I'm doing,
I have no idea what anything is,

but I like it.

Nothing seems apparent in the beginning, however, slowly but surely, you get a good feel for what's going on. The gameplay is solid - one part FPS, one part platforming. Both parts perform well, and while there are enemies hiding around every corner, somehow you feel like it's your fault if you die. Even though you may not see an enemy at first, you will see one of their bullets whizzing by your head, and that usually gives you enough time to react. My only gripe here is the cherry bomb - once it hits the ground, you have to restart the level, and it's a bit jarring at first because you have to experience it a couple of times to understand what happened and why.

As for level design, well... it all seems really repetetive. That's really all I have to say that's negatie, though. You play one short level after another, and there after you beat a level, it gives you your time and a 'record' time for you to beat. After enemies are introduced, it's your job to exterminate them. Miss one, and you have to start the level over. Concept is really simple. Difficulty curve is slow, if not spot on - new mechanics and enemies are gradually introduced to you so you have time to get used to what's happening.

Graphics-wise, everything is simple and polygonal, however, that just helps to boost the aesthetics. The environment is colorful and cheery, with bright pastel-like colors. The music is a nice touch as well - not fast, but still cheery and upbeat, fitting in quite nicely with the environment.

So should you get this game?

If you're into FPS games like CoD and Battlefield and such, no, this game is probably not for you - you will not be offered a high-octane competetive FPS, as that is not what this game is about.

However, if you want to relax and have some fun without the competition and fast paced gameplay, go for it. You'll have a lot of fun with this game - it's very easy to pick up and play.
